description.narrative: The report follow the original objectives and contains many interesting results and the below only presents some few high-lights in each area as space is limited. An additional section regarding overall and extraordinary Covid-19 response has been added at the beginning as it has been central to the work undertaken in 2020. Covid-19 response Certain activities had to be postponed during 2020 due tot he pandemic, especially internal human resources assessment and the change of the financial system. All of these will continue in 2021. It is also clear that quick adoption to the new realities was possible due to core support from Sida and Oak Foundation. - Blog series with analysis to further understand the covid-19 context, reaching its own community but also beyond, including a "WILPF guide to documenting and analysing responses to Covid-19 crisis". - Advocacy for feminist principles for post-Covid-19 recovery - where WILPF and the FIRE consortium partners (MADRE and Kvinna till kvinna) developed principles which were presented to the UN demanding action in six areas: ceasefire, gender based violence, health, environment, economy and militarism/security. - The set up of the "Feminist peace solidarity care fund" which provided 24 small-scale grants as short-term interventions by WILPF sections and groups in response to the pandemic. Many Sections and Groups used funds to distribute sanitizers, masks, and hand washing stations to help prevent the spread of COVID-19 in remote or under served communities. Supporting victims of gender-based violence and educating community members about the prevalence and effects of GBV was a primary focus for many funding recipients. Other WILPFers accessed the Solidarity Care Fund to support specific populations facing critical risk factors for COVID-19 and its impacts. The Section’s support also extended to individuals with limited literacy – the majority of whom are women and girls. Other WILPFers used their funds to help address the issue of food insecurity, which has emerged as a major worldwide crisis during COVID-19. - Solidarity dialogue in the MENA region between and with partners organisations resulting in a report documenting the changing contexts and current challenges andin support of WILPF advocacy for safer spaces in the region. Effort have also been made to safe guard the well being of staff when working remotely. 1. Transform gendered power - Understanding of gendered power and meaningful participation for women improves advocacy and actions for peace at global and local levels Indicator 1.1: Evidence of take-up of gender analysis and women’s meaningful participation among stakeholders, policymakers, key debates, and resolutions Evidence: WILPF contributed to the potential push back of a draft new WPS resolution which risked undermining gains and previously agreed language on human rights. The resolution was stopped from passing. Participation and support to participation in high-level foras like Arria Formulation, UNSC briefs, Informal Experts Group on Covid-19 from WILPF´s SG as well as local women leaders in Syria, Yemen and Afghanistan. Research and publications and policy briefs: UNSCR 1325 at 20 years: Perspectives of feminist peace activists and civil society, Where are the words? (lack of inclusion of WPS in country specific resolutions) and Bullets are cheaper than sugar (analysis of WPS in MENA) Improving normative language on gender in HRC resolution on fire arms which was picked up by some member countries. Contribution to Feminist Political Declaration (alternative to CSW political declaration) with the Womens Rights Caucus. Indicator 1.2: Evidence of take-up of gender analysis and women’s meaningful participation in national/local decision-making processes The new "Confronting militarised masculinities" initiative was put into operations in Afghanistan, Colombia, Cameroon and DRC and is done in collaboration with Men Engage but was slowed done due to Covid, travel restrictions and escalating violence. Supporting partners on integrating WPS and human rights advocacy to further teh agenda. In 2020 a fully online concept was used for Yemeni partners which covers UN HR mechanisms and international regulations on arms and resulted in a joint submission to CEDAW. 2. Stigmatise war and violence - Militarised thinking, systems and technologies of war are challenged at global and local levels WILPF has pushed the gendered aspects of disarmament for 20 years and the organisation continues to push for the connection between arms control, human rights and WPS. The work also contains lobbying for more ratifications of Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons, militarisation and securitisation of cyberspace and the impact of explosive weapons in populated areas (EWIPA). WILPF is quite alone in this niche of work and use Human Rights fora like UPR and CEDAW to pursue one of its core values. Indicator 2.1: Evidence of increased strength of analysis, active coalition building and/or shift in thinking/discourse Evidence: In 2020, 50 ratifications of the Treaty of the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons was achieved, meaning it entered into force i January 2021. This was the results of consistent efforts of WILPF, its partners and other civil society groups. WILPF has been part of the international advocacy team since 2017. The Treaty is now international binding law on its states parties and have normative effects worldwide. On the advocacy on accountability of States and of companies WILPF supported partners in Iraq with research and drafting of a report with recommendations - making arguments between the correlations of arms trade and violence against women. Lifting the inter linkages between arms trade and proliferation of human rights had notable impact in the Committee on Economic, Social and Cultural rights pre-sessions on Italy, leading to the most detailed questions on arms transfers ever made in the Committee (which normally does not address this) and now having this added to List of Issues which countries under review needs to incorporate in their follow-up reports and next reviews. Indicator 2.2: Evidence of outreach of analysis and advocacy on militarism, technologies and the arms trade A series of dialogue sessions, ‘Let’s Talk Cyber,’ was held to safe guard NGO inputs to the ongoing consultations of the UN’s Open-ended working group (OEWG) on developments of information and telecommunications in relation to international security. Articulating feminist perspectives on autonomous weapon systems has been applied on killer robots which was put into the focus last year and showed how WILPF can help make the issue relevant to common public. Two WILPF publications applied a broader inter sectional feminist analysis to these weapons in the context of war and policing. 3. Promote a feminist political economy - Feminist political economy (FPE) of peace promoted as a driver of analysis, accountability, and actions at global and local levels After initially working with this approach in Ukraine and Bosnia and Herzegovina, the concept to capture the gendered nature of the political economy in relation to peace building, WILPF has taken this work further steps ahead. WILPF shows how gender blind approaches to conflict and post-conflict reconstruction have negative impact on peace and has become the leading analytical tool of WILPF which it aims to mainstream both internally and externally. Indicator 3.1: Evidence of buy-in/take-up of feminist political economy approach in WILPF’s advocacy work Mainstreaming of FPE have included: training for delegates to CSW, integration into submissions to human rights mechanisms (CESCR Ukraine, CEDAW Zimbabwe, UPR Lebanon and for submission to CEDAW on trafficking for recommendation on global migration. advocacy on arms industry and business impact for women). Indicator 3.2: Outreach of FPE analysis and advocacy in different aspects of WILPF’s work Covid-19 blogs and articles have used FPE analysis when analysing responses and developments to the crisis from a feminist perspective which resulted in the "Feminist Principles for post COVID-19 settlement". Participation in two regional panels in South Eastern Europe, speaking on FPE in Covid-19 recovery in Bosnia and Herzegovina. 4. Movement building - WILPF and its contribution to the peace movement are strengthened The movement continued to be built despite Covid-19, using a variety of methods like small grants to sections, regional meetings and new spaces to support the WILPF community. Indicator 4.1: Evidence of increased effectiveness of WILPF’s internal processes Communication and Membership work have been strengthened during the year, to increasingly showcase stories and impact to create connection between members and the movement. Governance and diversity is at the core of the organisational development process WILPF has embarked upon with the support of Peace Nexus. The Black Life Matters movement has also influences WILPF to take clear stance against racism but also to to priorities internal work and commit to safe dialogue on the matter. Work to include environment has continued and a discussion paper was developed. A webinair series "Down the Green Feminist Road" was conducted, also connecting environment to militarism and holistic principle to environmental activism. This work includes contacts with UNEP to explore collaboration and in-puts on environment has gradually been incorporated in other advocacy work towards the HR-mechanisms (for Lebanon and Yemen in particular). An Environmental Working Group is established and an internal Environment and an internal Social Responsibility Policy and Action plan is in place. In December 2020 WILPF had a total of 42 staff and consultants. Indicator 4.2: Enhanced community of WILPF (Sections, Groups, members, partners) over five years WILPF has a total of 44 affiliated organisations: 32 Sections and 12 Groups globally. This shows a small downward trend from 2018 (47) but it is due to dormant sections and groups being removed by the board. If including countries where WILPF has partnerships for specific work it means a presence in 49 countries in total. Small grants to sections to support work related to NAPs, disarmament etc and flexible funding to women's rights and feminist organisations continued to be important method of this goal. Special focus has been on MENA, partly due to Norwegian funding for this purpose. The solidarity care fund has been a means during Covid-19 to allow for extraordinary activities to address immediate community needs. Indicator 4.3: Increased engagement of WILPF in coalition, networks, and with partners WILPF is growing its engagements for collective results and developed over 30 new partnerships during 2020, mainly for advocacy purpose, but also to deepen areas like research, NGO collaboration, sexual rights, accountability of states and companies on arms trade. WILPF also became one of the INGO partners to work with WPHF Rapid Response Window, a new initiative recently also getting support from Sida. WILPF will work in Libya, Afghanistan, Yemen and Syria. In 2019 the feminist FIRE consortium was formed, amongst others with two other Sida partners (MADRE and Kvinna till kvinna) to strengthen the feminist response and WPS and it grew stronger under 2020. FIRE developed the five feminist principles for meaningful ceasefire during the pandemic (see above). 5. Amplify local and regional change - Strengthen how women organise, meaningfully participate, and provide gender perspectives on root causes of conflict, conflict prevention, resolution, and peace process at local and national levels All planned activities and work in focus regions were impacted by the pandemic, however a lot of work could be carried out in all countries but with adjustments. Indicator 5.1: Local initiatives and activities implemented in focus countries and regions, and documented outcomes Afghanistan - The peace process has been the focus, to include women's meaningful participation and enhancing advocacy for girls and women with disabilities. WILPF could help disabled women feed into the peace talks in Doha and shared an advocacy briefing paper to the Minister of Peace which were to be presented to the taliban during peace negotiations. 20 years of advocacy for the official registration of a school for children with hearing impairments was finally successful - part of WILPF work with inclusion and diversity and an educations system accessible by all. Bosnia and Hercegovina - WILPF started a review process 25 years after the Dayton agreement which will be concluded mid-21 and continued to work and push for an alternative reform agenda on the ongoing process. Ukraine - WILPF and partners engaged in CESCR process (written statement, oral statements and participation) on womens rights, gendered impacts of cuts in social services, just workings conditions also for IDPs and GBV - many issues were pricked up into the joint report. Also in the CEDAW process a lot of the issues submitted will be included in the follow-up and next reporting cycle. MENA - Support to feminist grassroots organisations continued in Yemen, Iraq, Syria, Libya, Lebanon and Egypt, strengthening woman's participation in peace tracks, cross-regional exchanges and arabic feminist knowledge production. For example, training on CEDAW in Yemen, on gender conflict analysis for MENA partners, series of webinairs on Covid and gender justice, submissions to HR-mechanisms. Increased focus on stalled peace processes like local peace building in Libya, Syria and Yemen. Syria - 13 partner organisations continued to get support in order to enhance influence of women grass root activists in local and national consultations to identify women's priorities and challenges. WILPF provided safe space in Berlin for its partners to strategize for change. A submission to the Special Rapporteur on Syria on gender perspectives in transitional justice processes, based on broad community consultations. Yemen - WILPF was actively engaging with the Office of the Special Envoy for Yemen, including Trac 2 coordination meetings and on gender and ceasefire. It was also presenting recommendations on how to better include gender sensitive provisions in the joint declaration. Libya - WILPF has been part of organisations advocating for a fact-finding mission for human rights violations, which was finally put in place by UN Human Rights Council, and the advocacy efforts by WILPF ensured a gender perspective was integrated in the mandate. African region - the fastest growing WILPF region, many have been active in the Stop killer robot campaign and a lot of cross-learning have taken place between countries etc. WILPF Sweden has actively supported the regional growth and linked chapters in DRC and Zimbabwe with Swedish Embassies and youth networks. Cameroon - A gender conflict analysis project continued to address the root causes of conflict by collecting data on its impact on women and girls. The project is innovative and uses anthropological approaches to cases of violence. The method is to be adapted in other conflict contexts. Among other things, the project helped to bring visibility internationally and regionally to gender and conflict issues through participation. Nigeria - In the harsh realities activities and dialogues where held to enable the Nigerian Women Mediators Network operations. A social dialogue platform is created to allow a safe space. Colombia - LIMPAL had to intensify its works with survivors of GBV during the pandemic as lock-downs severely increased the number of cases. LIMPAL continued to share analysis of the implementation of the peace accord to the UN verification mission. Korean peninsula - WILPF is part of the Women Cross DMZ and the Korea Peace Now campaign to stop the war. Virtual events were held to build networks and share experiences of the war and its consequences. WILPF gave lectures to various grass root organisations and created interaction. Indicator 5.2: Frequency of dialogue and shared learning spaces for women’s civil society, including examples of follow-up and resulting actions for participants MENA virtual regional consultations treated Covid response as well as a series of webinairs on regional exchange - safe spaces to discuss how to work under lock-down and share best practise. 6. Improve multilateral actions - Accountability and integrated policies of the states, multilateral forums actively promoted WILPF has a long-term strategy to monitor and advocate multilateral foras to increase accountability and transparency and functions as a cross-cutting methodology. WILPF secretariat functions as a bridge between these spaces and the sections and realities on the ground. Results are captured in other areas Indicator 6.1: Documentation of WILPF monitoring of multilateral processes WILPF produces Security Council Monitor, National Action Plan Monitor and the UN Monitor. In 2019 WILPF made a strategic shift in the Security Council monitoring to focus more on mechanisms for implementation. It was the final year of the WPS Scorecard monitor of the five permanent members. The human rights program for example made detailed monitoring on the impact of Covid on civil society space at the HRC and its mechanisms. Indicator 6.2: Documentation of integration of thematic areas in multilateral actions (statements, policies, resolutions, outcomes, etc.) Despite the challenges a record number of submissions to multilateral foras by sections and partners continued in 2020. In all 52 statements were made to the UN, including 27 written submissions and 19 conference reports. For example, "A submission on the gendered impact of arms transfers to the Office of the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR) was made to advance feminist peace and challenge militarism. This is a particularly noteworthy achievement as some of WILPF’s suggestions on gender norms, power, and root causes of violence are reflected in the subsequent OHCHR report." Indicator 6.3: Evidence of “local to global to local” participation and analysis in multilateral forums This is notable throughout the report and a few additional examples are mentioned here: - WILPF’s disarmament programme contributed to the development of a political declaration against the use of explosive weapons in populated areas being led by the government of Ireland. - WILPF and its Partner, Peace Track Initiative (PTI), participated at the high-level virtual round table discussion on the impact of conflict on the rights of women and children in Yemen, hosted by the Permanent Mission of the UK based in New York. PTI briefed on women’s participation in the peace process and the impact of COVID-19 pandemic on the situation of women in Yemen. WILPF’s participation at the event was an important achievement in terms of civil society participation in such a dialogue. It is an ongoing priority for WILPF to work towards diminishing access barriers for civil society participation in government and multilateral forums. - WILPF Afghanistan Representative Jamila Afghani’s participation in the CEDAW committee’s session on Afghanistan and in a private round table. WILPF Afghanistan’s advocacy within CEDAW is a good example of a section’s active engagement with UN human rights mechanisms to advocate for changes at the national level.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The intended outcomes for the intervention is to strenghten a comprehensive integrated and child-sensitive social protection system in Ethiopia. The project is expected to lead to an increased number of children covered by social protection and increased public social protection expenditure for children. While cash transfers will lead to an increased income for identified beneficiaries, the system approach will support a long-term impact for poverty reduction.
The development of an effective social protection system is assessed as key to achieve sustainable reduction of child poverty. When beneficiaries and their children are linked to essential basic services according to their specific needs, this will lead to a general improvement of the lives of the most vulnerable who will be able to access basic services and targeted support.
The government and supply-side will also benefit from the systems approach through development of a standardised MIS, Management Information System, that can systematically link identified beneficiaries of the programme to tailor-made services and through development of a solid social workforce that can ensure that identified beneficiaries can access adequate services and possibly also build sustainable livelihoods.
Strengthening of a shock-responsive system of social protection that can respond early to emerging crises and increased vulnerability will contribute to strengthen resilience of people living in poverty. The development of a more shock-responsive social protection system is also expected to reduce the need for short-term humanitarian support.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Insatsen ska utveckla och stärka ett integrerat system för social trygghet med fokus på utsatta barn i Etiopien. Förmedling av kontantstöd ska bidra till ökad inkomst för utsatta grupper, samtidigt som uppbyggnad av en system-ansats för social trygghet kommer att bidra till att stärka de långsiktiga effekterna för fattigdomsminskning.
Insatsen ska leda till att fler barn omfattas av social trygghet och till ökad prioritering av offentlig social trygghet riktad till barn. Den förväntas också leda till mer effektiv koordinering inom systemet för social trygghet på nationell och regional nivå, samt till att skapa och sprida kunskap om effekter av social trygghet. Insatsen ska dessutom utveckla rurala och urbana program för social trygghet så att de förmår expandera sin räckvidd och sitt stöd vid Etiopiens återkommande akuta kriser som leder till ökad sårbarhet hos utsatta grupper.
Utvecklingen av ett effektivt system för social trygghet bedöms som en nyckelfråga för att uppnå långsiktigt hållbar minskning av barnfattigdom. När mottagare och deras barn länkas till grundläggande samhällsservice (som utbildning och hälsa) utifrån sina behov kommer det att leda till en generell förbättring av livskvalitet och välmående för de mest utsatta grupperna i samhället.
Regeringens kapacitet kommer att stärkas för att koordinera ett integrerat system för social trygghet och för att etablera och hantera ett informationssystem som länkar mottagare med skräddarsydd service och genom utbildning av socialarbetare som kan bidra till att identifierade mottagare får tillgång till service och möjligen också kan stärka sin egen inkomstgenerering.

The identified overall objectives for the project are: - SDG 1.3: Implement nationally appropriate social protection systems and measures for all, including floors, and by 2030 achieve substantial coverage of the poor and the vulnerable - UNDAP (2016-2020) By 2020 the Government of Ethiopia uses a social protection systems approach which ensures increased access to a comprehensive package of social protection programmes, interventions and services to poor and vulnerable citizens coping with social and economic risks, vulnerabilities and deprivations. - UNICEF CP (2016-2020) By 2020, Government capacity to develop, implement, coordinate and monitor a national. child-sensitive social protection system strengthened. Additional result ------------------------------- 1. To ensure effective and efficient implementation and management of child-sensitive social protection system within the of the ISNP and the overall sector in rural and urban areas through an increased focus on linkages creation to complementary social services as well as the integration of health care financing into the national social protection agenda as well as the core ISNP components. 2. To ensure maximum and multifaceted impact of the ISNP in rural and urban areas through the expansion of core ISNP programme components to one additional rural woreda in Amhara Region and one additional city. 3. To improve the effectiveness of PSNP’s response to shocks for both PSNP and non-PSNP households with children affected by malnutrition through contributing to the Federal Contingency Budget as well as advocacy at federal level. Expected results; i. Establishment of a comprehensive Linkages and Referral System as part of the urban (UPSNP) and rural (PSNP) Safety Net Programmes with a focus on direct support and destitute groups ii. Integration of health care financing (Community-based Health Insurance - CBHI) into the National Social Protection Agenda through successful piloting of harmonized implementation of the PSNP/UPSNP and the CBHI iii. Establishment of effective and efficient coordination and management of child-sensitive safety nets system at federal and regional level iv. Establishment of Social Workforce (social workers) System and CSO/NGO Collaboration v. Successful ISNP implementation in three rural woredas of Amhara. vi. Successful ISNP implementation in two urban centres of Ethiopia including Addis Ababa vii. Effective use of Federal PSNP Contingency Budget for households in PSNP woredas with malnourished children.

tag.narrative: 10.2 - By 2030, empower and promote the social, economic and political inclusion of all, irrespective of age, sex, disability, race, ethnicity, origin, religion or economic or other status.

10.2 - Till 2030 möjliggöra och verka för att alla människors, oavsett ålder, kön, funktionsnedsättning, ras, etnicitet, ursprung, religion eller ekonomisk eller annan ställning, blir inkluderade i det sociala, ekonomiska och politiska livet.
2.1 - By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.

2.1 - Senast 2030 avskaffa hunger och garantera alla människor, i synnerhet de fattiga och människor i utsatta situationer, inklusive små barn, tillgång till tillräckligt med säker och näringsrik mat året om.

3.8 - Achieve universal health coverage, including financial risk protection, access to quality essential health-care services and access to safe, effective, quality and affordable essential medicines and vaccines for all.

3.8 - Åstadkomma allmän hälso- och sjukvård för alla, som även skyddar mot ekonomisk risk, tillgång till grundläggande hälso- och sjukvård av god kvalitet liksom tillgång till säkra, effektiva och ekonomiskt överkomliga grundläggande läkemedel och vaccin av god kvalitet.
5.3 - Avskaffa alla skadliga sedvänjor, såsom barnäktenskap, tidiga äktenskap och tvångsäktenskap samt kvinnlig könsstympning.
5.3 - Eliminate all harmful practices, such as child, early and forced marriage and female genital mutilation.

description.narrative: Major results achieved during the implementation period in areas of Programme design/policy, system strengthening, innovations, and leveraging partnerships includes; - A dedicated output, service linkages, for the first time for MoLSA as part of PSNP 5. MoLSA's role has formally included and validated in all relevant documents of PSNP 5, unlike the previous phases, placing them on a more equal footing with Ministry of Agriculture and will ensure more resources are available. MoLSA will also lead the Permanent Direct Support (PDS) and Urban Destitute (UD) components with a dedicated budget in the new phase of PSNP - Integrated Safety Net Programme (ISNP) pilot model has been adopted and incorporated into RPNSP5: UNICEF, in collaboration with MoLSA, has been advocating and providing evidence of the importance of an integrated social protection system with social workers playing an integral role. - Community-Based Health Insurance (CBHI) continues to expand with increased number of clients enrolled. Moreover a 5-year strategy of the Ethiopian Health Insurance Agency was developed incorporating social protection concepts and equity issues. - Development of social worker curriculum ensuring continued deployment and professionalization/standardization of the social workforce. During the period Increased deployment of Social Workers was witnessed. - Ensuring systems are in place to strengthen coordination and sustainability, including (i) the establishment of a Federal Social Protection Platform and (ii) endorsement of Amhara Social Protection Fund - Innovative and adaptive approaches including Adaptive programming and advocacy for COVID-19 response and MoLSA's outreach expansion through NGOs for Urban Destitute target groups as part of UPSNP
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: COVID-19 UNICEF barn & mödrahälsa West Nile 2017-21
COVID-19 UNICEF maternal & newborn health West Nile 2017-21

description.narrative: New/additional funds to address COVID-19 Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Support to UNICEF for "Improving Maternal, Newborn and Child Health through Integrated Approaches in West Nile 2017-2018.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att bekämpa covid-19 Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Detta beslut är ett beslut om stöd till UNICEF för projektet "Improving Maternal, Newborn and Child Health through Integrated Approaches" i West Nile 2017-2018. Beslutet har inte föregåtts av beslut om beredning då stödet bygger på UNICEF:s liknande projekt i Karamoja-distriktet som ambassaden beslutade stödja i slutet av 2015. UNICEF har den 23 november 2016 inkommit med en ansökan till ambassaden för ovan nämnda program med en initial budget på 35 MSEK för 2017-2018.
Det föreslagna stödet till UNICEF syftar till att bidra till minskad mödra, neonatal och barnadödlighet samt förbättrad barnhälsa och utveckling i West Nile regionen, genom att stärka hälso- och sjukvårdssektorns kapacitet att tillhandahållanda mödra- och barnhälsovård av god kvalitet med fokus på integrerade och innovativa strategier. Projektets primära målgrupp är gravida kvinnor, nyblivna mödrar, nyfödda barn och barn under fem år i åtta distrikt i West Nile - en region som mottagit ett stort antal sydsudanesiska flyktingar.
West Nile regionen har några av de lägsta hälsoindikatorerna i Uganda, t.ex. antal vaccinerade barn, antal födslar på kliniker och användning av myggnät, med hög förekomst av malaria, diarré och hiv/aids. Regionen har en av de högsta nivåerna av barnadödlighet, där uppskattningsvis 125 barn dör innan de uppnått fem års åldern per 1000 levande födda barn, jämfört med Ugandas genomsnitt på 90. Sedan december 2013 har regionen sett en stor ökning av flyktingar från Sydsudan, vilket ansträngt den redan otillräckliga hälssosektorn ytterligare. Sedan konflikten intensifierades i juli i år har antalet flytkingar uppgått till över 30 000 per månad. För närvarande befinner sig över 500 000 sydsudanesiska flyktingar i West Nile regionen, varav cirka 86 procent är kvinnor och barn.
UNICEF arbetar både med utvecklings- och humanitärt bistånd och är en av UNHCR:s och regeringens viktigaste partners i flyktingmottagandet, med fokus på livräddande åtgärder inom hälsa, nutrition, vatten, sanitet och hygien. Sveriges nuvarande resultatstrategi för Uganda fokuserar inte på att stärka länken mellan utvecklingsstöd och humanitärt bistånd, katastrofriskreducering (DRR) eller resiliens. Det föreslagna stödet till UNICEF syftar därför till att stärka kapaciteten inom hälsosektorn i West Nile samt möta upp det ökade behovet av hälso- och sjukvårdstjänster och den humanitära responsen i de distrikt som mottar störst andel flyktingar. Genom att stödja UNICEF:s reguljära verksamhet i West Nile kan UNICEF även frigöra medel för sin humanitära verksamhet, idag allvarligt underfinansierad.

tag.narrative: 3.1 - By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.
3.1 - Till 2030 minska mödradödligheten i världen till mindre än 70 dödsfall per 100 000 förlossningar med levande barn.

3.2 - By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births.

3.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att inga spädbarn eller barn under fem år dör av orsaker som hade kunnat förebyggas. Alla länder bör sträva efter att minska den neonatala dödligheten till högst tolv dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda och dödligheten bland barn under fem år till högst 25 dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda.

3.8 - Achieve universal health coverage, including financial risk protection, access to quality essential health-care services and access to safe, effective, quality and affordable essential medicines and vaccines for all.

3.8 - Åstadkomma allmän hälso- och sjukvård för alla, som även skyddar mot ekonomisk risk, tillgång till grundläggande hälso- och sjukvård av god kvalitet liksom tillgång till säkra, effektiva och ekonomiskt överkomliga grundläggande läkemedel och vaccin av god kvalitet.

5.6 - Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.

5.6 - Säkerställa allmän tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och reproduktiva rättigheter i enlighet med överenskommelserna i handlingsprogrammet från den internationella konferensen om befolkning och utveckling, Pekingplattformen samt slutdokumenten från respektive översynskonferenser.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: The intervention addresses the underlying causes of poor health and nutrition outcomes in children, adolescents and women in West Nile and targets both refugee and host populations. The activities are aligned with the Uganda Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn, Child and Adolescent Health (RMNCAH) Sharpened Plan and the Integrated Health Sector Refugee Response Plan. The analysis below is based on the annual narrative and financial report for 2019 and dialogue with UNICEF during Jan-Sep 2020 including a bi-annual review meeting held on 2nd September. Summary of key resultsUNICEF summarises the main achievements from the 2017 onset of the intervention as follows: - Improved access and coverage of antenatal and delivery care- Improved quality of care for maternal and newborn health- Strengthened capacity for planning and data systems at the national level- Improved governance at the district and health facility level- Improved physical environment through WASH, rehabilitation and lighting The first achievement is exemplified by an increase in four or more antenatal care (ANC) visits from 40% to 51% and 52% in 2017, 2018 and 2019 respectively, with seven out of eleven districts reporting an increase. The slow increase in 2019 is assessed by UNICEF as a result of late care-seeking behaviour by pregnant mothers, due to fear of disclosure of pregnancy and they intend to address it by strengthened community mobilisation and and engagement. The latter activities are however already part of the intervention why it can be discussed how effective they are in changing social norms and thereby care-seeking behavior. The question was put by Sida at the bi-annual review meeting, but without any conclusive answer other than that it's challenging to achieve behavioural change. In total, 69% of pregnant mothers were reported to have delivered in health facilities in the region in 2019, compared to 70% in 2018. While below the national target of 80% it is above the national average of 63 %. District performance is measured using an MoH methodology that rates districts based on performance against indicators such as health facility deliveries, maternal death reviews and completeness of reports. Over the entire project period, four districts have improved while four declined. Reasons for decline vary, but e.g. in Arua district it's mainly attributed to weak leadership and an increasing number of migrants who are not captured as refugees but still stretch the health system. Yumbe district which also shows a significant decline in performance, host the largest number of refugees in the region and in 2019 the refugee population was added to the denominators which contributed to the drop in performance. An important achievement worth separate mentioning is that thanks to Sida's support, eight out of ten districts are by December 2019 providing adolescent health services. The support includes mentorship, establishment of special adolescent clinics in some health facilities and community dialogues targeting the young people in the catchment area. At the onset of the project in 2017 adolescent services were completely absent in the targeted districts. UNICEF also reports that the intervention has been "instrumental in improving: i) district health managers’ capacity to use data for evidence-based planning, budgeting and monitoring of RMNCAH services; ii) competency and skills of frontline health workers; and iii) availability of equipment and improvements in the physical environment in targeted health facilities." Output examples are: - construction of WASH facilities such as solar-powered water systems, latrines, bath shelters, incinerators, and placenta pits in twelve health facilities. - In 2019, an additional 23 health facilities were reported to have labour rooms which were WASH compliant, indicating a 15 per cent improvement from 2018, which further contributed to the functionalization of health centre IVs in the region. - Eight hospitals and fourteen health centres were equipped with essential equipment for maternal and newborn care. Special Care Units for newborns were established in two additional hospitals (Nebbi and Maracha). Cumulatively, 10 of the targeted 20 CEmONC (Comprehensive Emergency Obstetric and Neonatal Care) facilities had functional newborn care units by the end of 2019. - In 2019 UNICEF supported the training of 99 midwives in all the four modules of EmONC. This is in addition to the 180 and 92 doctors and midwives who were trained in 2017 and 2018, respectively. - In 2019 388 health workers from 127 health facilities were covered by on-the-job mentorship and supportive supervision. - In 2019 UNICEF supported the construction of WASH facilities in 10 health care facilities (seven HC IIIs and three HC IIs), including ten solar-powered water systems with distribution to maternity, laboratory and other wards, twenty latrines, eighteen bath shelters, nine incinerators and four placenta pits. - To address the second delay leading to maternal and neonatal deaths, UNICEF, with Sida funds, supported inter-facility referrals of pregnant mothers with obstetric and newborn complications. In 2019, 588 ambulance referrals were supported in West Nile, 98.5 per cent (579/588) of which were mothers, and 1.5 per cent (9/588) were children under five. There is no doubt that the intervention is well-managed and overall is performing well. What is lacking in the reporting is an aggregated aggregated analysis of progress beyond the quantitative indicator specific measuring which of course is also important. There is limited space given to elaboration on the overall trajectory towards strengthened health sector capacity which is the overarching objective of the intervention. This was shared in writing as feedback on the annual report and communicated during the bi-annual review meeting where UNICEF took note. Improvements are expected in the next report due on 30th June 2021. CommunicationIt should be noted that UNICEF have been very active with communication efforts, producing and publishing several stories and being active on social media. The Embassy and Sida have been able to successfully piggy-back on these efforts for good visibility in Sida both in Uganda and for our Swedish constituency. Impact of Covid-19As a result of the Covid-19 pandemic, all embassies in Africa with development cooperation strategies were on March 18th 2020 tasked by Sida's Africa Department to engage in dialogue with all partners on i) implementation risks, ii) need for adaptation and iii) ideas about new initiatives. This resulted in adjustments of several contributions including reprogramming of funds, across the portfolio. The dialogue with UNICEF concerning this programme had already on 11th May lead to reprogramming of USD 100,700 to Covid-19 related mitigation and response activities (minor amendment of contribution). With additional funding becoming available and with UNICEF being a key partner within health and playing an important role in supporting the national response to the pandemic, Sida approached UNICEF to enquire about their absorption capacity and operational priorities. In the early stages of the dialogue, UNICEF expressed both the need for additional resources and the absorption capacity. Hence, Sida requested a supplementary funding proposal for an extension of the existing programme, with focus both on support to the continuation of essential health services, in order to mitigate the negative impacts of restrictions, and to direct covid-19 response activities. The proposed activities were assessed as fully in line with Sida's request and the decision was made 30 June 2020 to add SEK 42m, to extend the activity period with 12 months until 31st August 2021 and the validity of the agreement until 31 December 2022. Through the decision UNICEF were given the flexibility to go beyond the original programme's geographic focus on the West Nile region in order to be fully needs based. This is reflected in the inclusion of only non West Nile districts for the pandemic response activities (outcome 1) and the inclusion of the Kawempe referral hospital for support to continuity of essential services under outcome 2, which otherwise only focuses on West Nile. Kawempe Hospital serves as the national referral hospital focusing on maternal, newborn and child health conditions and delivers 80-120 mothers daily of which approximately 30 % require c-section and over 10% require critical care. The support to Kawempe is motivated by Kampala having the highest numbers of maternal deaths between July 2019 and April 2020, with an institutional maternal mortality ratio at 145.8 against a national average of 93.5 per 100,000 deliveries. Approximately 71% of these deaths were registered in Kawempe Hospital. Furthermore, the monthly average for maternal deaths has increased in the context of Covid-19 with more than half of the deaths happening between January and April 2020. The focus of the intervention on preventing and addressing the secondary impact of the outbreak on the most vulnerable communities in alignment with Sida’s application of a multidimensional poverty perspective in Uganda. The intervention reduces the risk that those reached will fall deeper into poverty or fall back into poverty since there is a strong link between livelihood opportunities and access to qualitative health care. Both are together with people’s individual health status key indicators looked at in the multidimensional poverty analysis (MDPA) and directly affected by Covid-19. The continued main geographical focus on West Nile further aligns with the MDPA conducted by Sida in 2017 which showed that the sub-region is among the poorest and least developed in the country. Financial managementThe certified financial statement does not allow for comparison with the output based operational budget. While not a requirement in the agreement the narrative report would have benefited from an expanded section on financial implementation, elaborating e.g. on expenditure rates, deviations, re-allocations and forecast for the use of the remaining balances. This was shared in writing and at the bi-annual review meeting at which UNICEF also reported that all funds had now been used. One of the water infrastructure contractors was slightly delayed due to covid-19, but work was expected to be concluded before the end of October. There are no remaining payments under this agreement.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

tag.narrative: 10.3 - Ensure equal opportunity and reduce inequalities of outcome, including by eliminating discriminatory laws, policies and practices and promoting appropriate legislation, policies and action in this regard.

10.3 - Säkerställa lika möjligheter och minska förekomsten av ojämlika utfall, bland annat genom att avskaffa diskriminerande lagstiftning, politik och praxis och främja lagstiftning, politik och åtgärder av lämpligt slag i detta hänseende.
16.10 - 0 Säkerställa allmän tillgång till information och skydda grundläggande friheter, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning och internationella avtal.

16.3 - Främja rättssäkerheten på nationell och internationell nivå samt säkerställa lika tillgång till rättvisa för alla.
16.3 - Promote the rule of law at the national and international levels and ensure equal access to justice for all.
16.5 - Substantially reduce corruption and bribery in all their forms.
16.5 - Väsentligt minska alla former av korruption och mutor.
16.6 - Bygga upp effektiva och transparenta institutioner med ansvarsutkrävande på alla nivåer.
16.6 - Develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels.
16.7 - Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.
16.7 - Säkerställa ett lyhört, inkluderande, deltagandebaserat och representativt beslutsfattande på alla nivåer.
16.b - Promote and enforce non-discriminatory laws and policies for sustainable development.
16.b - Verka för och genomdriva icke-diskriminerande lagstiftning och politik för en hållbar utveckling.
5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.
5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.
5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.

description.narrative: Examples of key results observed from this contribution during 2017-2021: - A CSO-law (2018) enabling CSO human rights advocacy (compared to very repressive legislation previously) -Strengthened functions and reforms for independence of justice through attorney general/the courts.- Improved capacities of the electoral commission (NEBE), including electoral legislation and proceedures in accordance with international standards.- Enhanced independence, mandate, functioning and activity of the human rights commission in raising andfollowing up on human rights abuses, including in Tigray but also in other Ethiopian regions.- A new media policy (2020) for enhanced freedom of expression and strengthened media independence.- COVID-adaptation within Ethiopian governance structures, including special mechanisms at courts against GBV, strategies against anti-corruption especially targeting the health sector where increased risks were identified under the pandemic, and an e-governance system at the Ombudsman to enhance respons to citizens.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Insatsen bygger på tidigare svenskt stöd till media-reformer i Etiopien. Kopplat till aktuella, pågående demokratiska reformer i Etiopien syftar projektet till att ta tillvara möjligheterna att skapa förhållanden för att uppnå följande resultat:
- Nyckelaktörer stärks i arbetet med att utveckla ett juridiskt och institutionellt ramverk som stödjer en fri och oberoende media, garanterar tillgången till information och underlättar för informerade och engagerade medborgare; - Målgrupper inom media får stärkt finansiell hållbarhet och publicerar media av allmänt intresse, inklusive bland kvinnor, män, olika åldersgrupper samt olika befolkningsgrupper.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 This contribution builds upon previous Swedish support to media reforms in Ethiopia. Seizing opportunities created by the current on-going democratic reforms in Ethiopia, the project aims to contribute to the following objectives:
- Key actors are strengthened to contribute to developing and implementing a legislative and institutional framework that supports a free and self-regulating media, ensures public access to information and promotes an informed and engaged citizenry; - Targeted media are strengthened to become financially sustainable and to produce and disseminate public interest journalism, reflecting the full composition of society through a balanced presence of women and men, age groups and communities.

The programmes overall objective is to insure that "men and women in Ethiopia have access to independent and balanced interest journalism, enabling democratic and peaceful citizen engagement and accountable governance" Two specific objectives are "key actors contribute to an overall media reform in Ethiopia to ensure an open, diverse and democratic media landscape, and to the production and dissemination of public interest journalism characterized by professionalism, gender equality and inclusive community engagement" and "Women, men and youth living in marginalized communities, including refugees, IDPs and hosts, to exercise their agency to initiate and participate in inclusive public dialogue and discussions" In line with this, two main outcomes have been defined: Outcome 1: Key actors are strengthened to contribute to developing and implementing a legislative and institutional framework that supports a free and self-regulated media, ensures public access to information and promotes an informed and engaged citizenry. Outcome 2: Targeted media are strengthened to become financially sustainable and to produce and disseminate public interest journalism, reflecting the full composition of society through a balanced presence of women and men, age groups and communities.

title.narrative: COVID-19 Oxfam DRC Governance and community protection Program -Our rights and our duties
COVID-19 Oxfam DRC Governance and community protection Program -Our rights and our duties

description.narrative: In its essence, the program aims to create new and transform existing relationships to bring about a shift in the power relations that currently keep women subordinate to men, youth and minorities excluded from opportunities, and citizens subject to the will of authorities. Once created or changed, new relationships will be nurtured, strengthened and sustained to the extent that they are deemed valuable by those who are party to them. Oxfam proposes a program to advance the goal of a DRC in which women and men, civil society organizations, and community groups are able to exercise their rights, secure protection from violence and abuse, voice priorities, and participate in decisions that affect their lives. To achieve this, in this program Oxfam will be working in two provinces in East (South Kivu and Tanganyika) and one in the West (Equateur) of the DRC. The program will: - Enable communities, local public institutions and CSOs to adopt new or change current practices and attitudes to increase respect for human rights and women’s rights, and reduce discrimination and violence; - Support community-level governance committees, including women’s forums, to build the capacity and confidence for collective action that engages territorial and provincial authorities to improve the accountability of governance, respect for gender equality and effectiveness of protection processes; - Establish and facilitate a citizen-state consultation process by which authorities at provincial, territorial and local levels adopt practices and procedures in response to citizens’ demands for increased accountability, transparency, inclusiveness of governance, increased respect for gender equality and increased protection of citizens’ rights; - Strengthen the capacity of national advocacy organizations to apply an evidence-based approach that represents the views and incorporates the testimonies drawn directly from local civil society organizations and ordinary citizens, to be more effective and credible in their advocacy efforts. To demonstrate the possibility and test a model of effective bottom-up change in DRC, Oxfam will build on programs proven effective in bringing about lasting individual and local level change, to address the more systemic governance, protection and equality issues that can only be achieved with engagement by higher levels of government. The program’s direct beneficiaries will be the individuals trained to serve as change agents; as well as the community governance structure, women’s forum members, local, territorial and provincial formal and traditional authorities who participate in program trainings and other activities. Direct beneficiaries (examples) 720 Change agents trained in 24 locations, 50% men, 50% women, 30% of the total youth Each change agent will reach out to at least 15 people in the project cycle – which leads to 10 800 change agents. Change agents will reach out at least to 2 public institutions at the community level: 48 public institutions and interaction with several individuals from each institution Indirect beneficiaries: 72,000 community members in rural areas, based on communities of 3,000 inhabitants 500,000 through communication activities (including reach on social networks) Indirect beneficiaries at territorial, provincial and national level will be assessed during start-up phase

Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Oxfam har ansökt om finansiering på 52 901 215 SEK från Sida för att genomföra programmet “Governance and Community Protection Program 2018-2022 - our rights our duties in DRC” under perioden 2018 till 2022.
Programmet förväntas bidra till att kvinnor och män, civilsamhällsorganisationer och andra samhällsgrupper bättre: * kan utöva sina rättigheter * kan få ökat skydd mot våld och övergrepp * stärker sina röster och bättre kan delta i beslut som påverkar deras liv
Programmet omfattar: *Stöd till lokala offentliga institutioner och civilsamhällsorganisationer för vägledning till att införa nya, eller förändra rådande policys och attityder för ökad respekt för mänskliga rättigheter och kvinnors rättigheter samt för att minska diskriminering och våld.
* Stöd till kommittéer på lokal nivå, inklusive kvinnoforum, så att de kan stärka sin kapacitet och öka sitt förtroende för kollektiva åtgärder. Detta för att de ska kunna ställa högre krav på lokala och provinsiella myndigheter kring förbättrad förvaltning, respekt för jämställdhet och effektivitet i skyddsprocesser.
* Arbeta för att myndigheter på provinsiell och lokal nivå antar och förstärker praxis och processer i enlighet med medborgarnas krav. Dessa krav ska förverkligas genom regionala samrådsprocesser på medborgarnivå. Arbetet kommer att präglas av ökat ansvarsutkrävande, transparens, inkludering, ökad respekt för jämställdhet samt skydd av medborgerliga rättigheter.
• Stärka nationella organisationers förmåga att på ett bevisbaserat sätt som representera medborgarnas åsikter och införliva de vittnesmål som kommer från lokala civila samhällsorganisationer. Detta för att de ska vara mer effektiva och trovärdiga i sin plädering för förändring.
Oxfam kommer att genomföra insatsen tillsammans med lokala organisationer i tre provinser: Equateur, Syd-Kivu och Tanganyika. Insatsens totala budget uppgår till 52 901 215 SEK och Sida är den enda givaren till programmet.

Oxfam DRC Governance and Community Protection Program - Concept Note

description.narrative: In its essence, the program aims to create new and transform existing relationships to bring about a shift in the power relations that currently keep women subordinate to men, youth and minorities excluded from opportunities, and citizens subject to the will of authorities. Once created or changed, new relationships will be nurtured, strengthened and sustained to the extent that they are deemed valuable by those who are party to them. Oxfam proposes a program to advance the goal of a DRC in which women and men, civil society organizations, and community groups are able to exercise their rights, secure protection from violence and abuse, voice priorities, and participate in decisions that affect their lives. To achieve this, in this program Oxfam will be working in two provinces in East (South Kivu and Tanganyika) and one in the West (Equateur) of the DRC. The program will: - Enable communities, local public institutions and CSOs to adopt new or change current practices and attitudes to increase respect for human rights and women’s rights, and reduce discrimination and violence; - Support community-level governance committees, including women’s forums, to build the capacity and confidence for collective action that engages territorial and provincial authorities to improve the accountability of governance, respect for gender equality and effectiveness of protection processes; - Establish and facilitate a citizen-state consultation process by which authorities at provincial, territorial and local levels adopt practices and procedures in response to citizens’ demands for increased accountability, transparency, inclusiveness of governance, increased respect for gender equality and increased protection of citizens’ rights; - Strengthen the capacity of national advocacy organizations to apply an evidence-based approach that represents the views and incorporates the testimonies drawn directly from local civil society organizations and ordinary citizens, to be more effective and credible in their advocacy efforts. To demonstrate the possibility and test a model of effective bottom-up change in DRC, Oxfam will build on programs proven effective in bringing about lasting individual and local level change, to address the more systemic governance, protection and equality issues that can only be achieved with engagement by higher levels of government. The program’s direct beneficiaries will be the individuals trained to serve as change agents; as well as the community governance structure, women’s forum members, local, territorial and provincial formal and traditional authorities who participate in program trainings and other activities. Direct beneficiaries (examples) 720 Change agents trained in 24 locations, 50% men, 50% women, 30% of the total youth Each change agent will reach out to at least 15 people in the project cycle – which leads to 10 800 change agents. Change agents will reach out at least to 2 public institutions at the community level: 48 public institutions and interaction with several individuals from each institution Indirect beneficiaries: 72,000 community members in rural areas, based on communities of 3,000 inhabitants 500,000 through communication activities (including reach on social networks) Indirect beneficiaries at territorial, provincial and national level will be assessed during start-up phase

Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Oxfam har ansökt om finansiering på 52 901 215 SEK från Sida för att genomföra programmet “Governance and Community Protection Program 2018-2022 - our rights our duties in DRC” under perioden 2018 till 2022.
Programmet förväntas bidra till att kvinnor och män, civilsamhällsorganisationer och andra samhällsgrupper bättre: * kan utöva sina rättigheter * kan få ökat skydd mot våld och övergrepp * stärker sina röster och bättre kan delta i beslut som påverkar deras liv
Programmet omfattar: *Stöd till lokala offentliga institutioner och civilsamhällsorganisationer för vägledning till att införa nya, eller förändra rådande policys och attityder för ökad respekt för mänskliga rättigheter och kvinnors rättigheter samt för att minska diskriminering och våld.
* Stöd till kommittéer på lokal nivå, inklusive kvinnoforum, så att de kan stärka sin kapacitet och öka sitt förtroende för kollektiva åtgärder. Detta för att de ska kunna ställa högre krav på lokala och provinsiella myndigheter kring förbättrad förvaltning, respekt för jämställdhet och effektivitet i skyddsprocesser.
* Arbeta för att myndigheter på provinsiell och lokal nivå antar och förstärker praxis och processer i enlighet med medborgarnas krav. Dessa krav ska förverkligas genom regionala samrådsprocesser på medborgarnivå. Arbetet kommer att präglas av ökat ansvarsutkrävande, transparens, inkludering, ökad respekt för jämställdhet samt skydd av medborgerliga rättigheter.
• Stärka nationella organisationers förmåga att på ett bevisbaserat sätt som representera medborgarnas åsikter och införliva de vittnesmål som kommer från lokala civila samhällsorganisationer. Detta för att de ska vara mer effektiva och trovärdiga i sin plädering för förändring.
Oxfam kommer att genomföra insatsen tillsammans med lokala organisationer i tre provinser: Equateur, Syd-Kivu och Tanganyika. Insatsens totala budget uppgår till 52 901 215 SEK och Sida är den enda givaren till programmet.

description.narrative: Regional Emergency Response - COVID-19 and human rights The intervention seeks to strengthen OHCHR’s capacity to prevent and respond to serious violations of international human rights and humanitarian law, including in the context of COVID-19; and at the same time, support the wider United Nations effort to become more effective in anticipating, preventing and responding to crisis and conflict. Two outcomes are presented for the intervention: i) decision-makers at the global, national and regional level take preventive measures and early action to address serious violations of international human rights and humanitarian law, including negative socio-economic and other human rights impacts of COVID-19 response and recovery measures, with a focus on vulnerable populations: ii) Enhanced access to early warning analysis of the human rights situation by national partners in impacted regions To deliver on this commitment, OHCHR will improve how it identifies, manages, analyses and leverages human rights information to support strategic and operational decisions. This is accomplished by putting human rights officers and information management professionals in the field – the Emergency Response Teams – to support operations and engage with information channels in humanitarian and development as well as human rights contexts. Targeting resources to support field presences is expected to lead to more actionable data and information, with OHCHR better able to identify emerging risks and promising practices; and provide the situational awareness required to inform the timely, evidence-based, strategic and operational decisions made by the United Nations System and Member States. Contingency Fund The intervention seeks to strengthen OHCHR’s capacity to respond to human rights deteriorating situations currently arising from pandemic and to ensure that a Human Rights-Based Approach is integrated in all UN responses at the global, regional and country levels. In the context of the ongoing OHCHR’s COVID-19 response, the Contingency Fund would be used to enable the deployment of a temporary surge capacity (local recruitment/deployment of a temporary Human Rights Officer) in an OHCHR field presence (in person and/or remotely, as travel restrictions allow) to assist UN Country Teams/Humanitarian Country Teams. OHCHR would activate the use of the Contingency Fund at the initiative of High Commissioner in response to:- Unexpected deteriorating or potentially deteriorating human rights situations- A request by a Representative of the United Nations system in a country - A request by an OHCHR Head of Field Presence; in support to inter-agency efforts, including during a humanitarian crisis.

Stöd till OHCHR - UN Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights - och deras globala Covid-response program. Det inbegriper dels stöd till Emergency Response Teams, och dels Contingency Fund.
OHCHR har ansökt om 40 000 000 SEK i stöd för att expandera programmen (i) Emergency Response Teams och (ii) Contingency Fund för OHCHRs globala COVID-respons under 2020-2022.
Insatserna strävar efter att stärka OHCHR:s närvaro i fält för att öka inkludering och implementering av mänskliga rättigheter i regionala samt nationella COVID-responsprogram.
Programmens gemensamma totala budget är 13 201 784 USD,(10 201 784 USD för ERT och 3 000 000 USD för CF) där Sida står för 40 000 000 SEK. 35 500 000 SEK av stödet kommer att gå till Emergency Response Teams och 4 500 000 SEK går till Contingency Fund.

Support to OHCHR - UN Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights - and their global Covid-response programmes. That includes (i) support to the Emergency Response Teams and (i) support to Contingency Fund at regional hubs and HQ.
OHCHR has applied to Sida for funding of SEK 40 000 000 to carry out and expand the Emergency Response Teams and Contingency Fund to respond to the global COVID-19 pandemic during the period 2020-2022.
The interventions aim at expanding and strengthening the field presence of OHCHR to assure human rights are incorporated in regional and national programmes inlcuding COVID-response programmes by deploying expertise to build capacity within the field offices.
The programmes' total budget is USD 13 201 784, out of which Sida contributes with SEK 40 000 000. The support will be divided between both programmes, where SEK 35 500 000 will be directed to the ERTs and SEK 4 500 000 to the Contingency Fund.

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Asia Disaster Preparedness Center, ADPC, har av Sida ansökt om ca 5 933 0000 USD (54 miljoner kronor) för att genomföra "Building resilience through inclusive and climate-adaptive disaster risk reduction in Asia-Pacific 2017-2021” i Asien och Stillahavsområdet under perioden 2017-2021.
ADPC är en icke-vinstdrivande regional organisation som grundades 1999 och arbetar för säkrare samhällen och en hållbar utveckling genom katastrofminskning i Asien och Stillahavsområdet. ADPC: s genomför genom projekt och program utbildning, information- och kunskapshantering samt annat tekniskt stöd avseende katastrofriskreduktion. ADPC samarbetar med lokala, nationella och regionala regeringar, statliga och icke-statliga organisationer, givare och utvecklingspartners för att uppnå sina mål inom katastrofriskreducering. ADPC’s regionala kontor ligger i Bangkok och man har landkontor i Bangladesh, Myanmar och Sri Lanka. ADPC är sedan år 2000 sekretariat för Regional Consultative Committee on disaster management (RCC) vilket består av National Disaster Management Organisations (NDMO’s) från 26 länder* i Asien och Stillahavsområdet. RCC är ett unikt forum som fokuserar på genomförandet av katastrof- och klimatriskhanteringsinitiativ samt samarbetar kring genomförandet av de globala och regionala ramverken inom utvecklingsagendan på nationell och regional nivå.
Det femåriga programmet syftar till att förbättra den regionala kapaciteten för samarbete gällande katastrof- och klimatriskhantering med det övergripande målet att bygga motståndskraft och anpassningsförmåga hos människor i Asien och Stillahavsområdet. Programmet arbetar med nationella myndigheter, civilsamhälls-organisationer och regionala organisationer genom Regional Consultative Committee on Disaster Management’s (RCC’s) vars medlemmar är katastrofhanteringsmyndigheter i 26 Asiatiska länder. Programmets huvudfokusområden är: katastrofberedskap och hantering av humanitär respons; ökad användning av riskinformation och data uppdelat efter gender, ålder och handikapp; integrering av katastrof- och klimatfrågor i nationella och regionala utvecklingsprogram och i policy; ökad användning av inkluderande tillvägagångssätt inom riskreducering och katastrofberedskap; främjande av jämställdhet och kvinnligt ledarskap inom riskhantering, samt stärkande av Regional Consultative Committee on Disaster Management’s (RCC’s) och dess regionala roll som stöd till medlemsländerna i genomförandet av globala överenskommelser och facilitator för syd-syd-lärande, gränsöverskridande riskreducering och kunskapsdelning. Direkt målgrupp för programmet är framförallt nationella katastrofmyndigheter genom RCC. Slutlig målgrupp är kvinnor och andra särskilt utsatta grupper. Förslaget nämner inte ursprungsbefolkningar per se men fokuserar på mest riskutsatta grupper. ADPC kommer att genomföra programmet tillsammans med Myndigheten för Samhällsskydd och Bevarande (MSB), Stockholm Environment Institute (SEI-Asia) och Raul Wallenberg-institutet (RWI).
*Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Bhutan, Brunei, Cambodia, China, Georgia, India, Indonesia, Iran, Jordan, Kazakhstan, Lao PDR, Malaysia, Maldives, Mongolia, Myanmar, Nepal, Pakistan, Papua New Guinea, Philippines, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Thailand, Timor Leste, Vietnam

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Asia Disaster Preparedness Center, ADPC, has applied to Sida for funding of 5 933 000 USD (54 million SEK) to carry out the "Building resilience through inclusive and climate-adaptive disaster risk reduction in Asia-Pacific" in Asia and Pacific during the period 2017-2022.
The five-year program aims to enhance regional capacity for cooperation on disaster and climate risk management with an overall objective of building resilience of people in the Asia-Pacific region. This will be achieved by building on current good practices and providing technical assistance to select governments, civil society organizations and regional bodies. Key focus areas of the program include: emergency preparedness and humanitarian response management; facilitating the use of risk information and sex-age-disability-disaggregated data by policy makers and disaster managers; integrating disaster and climate change concerns into development policy and programs; promoting inclusion and protection-sensitive approaches in risk reduction and disaster preparedness, promoting gender equality and women leadership for risk resilience; and enhancing the role of the Regional Consultative Committee on Disaster Management (RCC) to support member countries on implementing global frameworks and serving as a conduit for South-South learning, transboundary risk reduction and knowledge sharing. ADPC will implement the intervention together with the Swedish Contingency Agency, MSB, Stockholm Environment Institute –Asia, and the Raul Wallenberg Institute.

tag.narrative: 1.5 - By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters.

1.5 - Till 2030 bygga upp motståndskraften hos de fattiga och människor i utsatta situationer och minska deras utsatthet och sårbarhet för extrema klimatrelaterade händelser och andra ekonomiska, sociala och miljömässiga chocker och katastrofer.

11.5 - By 2030, significantly reduce the number of deaths and the number of people affected and substantially decrease the direct economic losses relative to global gross domestic product caused by disasters, including water-related disasters, with a focus on protecting the poor and people in vulnerable situations.

11.5 - Till 2030 väsentligt minska antalet dödsfall och antalet människor som drabbas av katastrofer, inklusive vattenrelaterade katastrofer. Även tillse att de direkta ekonomiska förlusterna till följd av sådana katastrofer, i form av lägre global BNP, minskar väsentligt. Särskilt fokus bör ligga på att skydda de fattiga och människor i utsatta situationer.

11.b - By 2020, substantially increase the number of cities and human settlements adopting and implementing integrated policies and plans towards inclusion, resource efficiency, mitigation and adaptation to climate change, resilience to disasters, and develop and implement, in line with the Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction 2015–2030, holistic disaster risk management at all levels.

11.b - Till 2020 väsentligen öka det antal städer och samhällen som antar och genomför integrerade strategier och planer för inkludering, resurseffektivitet, begränsning av och anpassning till klimatförändringarna och motståndskraft mot katastrofer samt utveckla och genomföra, i linje med Sendai-ramverket för katastrofriskreducering 2015–2030, en samlad katastrofriskhantering på alla nivåer.
13.1 - Strengthen resilience and adaptive capacity to climate-related hazards and natural disasters in all countries.
13.1 - Stärka motståndskraften mot och förmågan till anpassning till klimatrelaterade faror och naturkatastrofer i alla länder.
13.2 - Integrate climate change measures into national policies, strategies and planning.
13.2 - Integrera klimatåtgärder i politik, strategier och planering på nationell nivå.

13.3 - Förbättra utbildningen, medvetenheten och den mänskliga och institutionella kapaciteten vad gäller begränsning av klimatförändringarna, klimatanpassning, begränsning av klimatförändringarnas konsekvenser samt tidig varning.
13.3 - Improve education, awareness-raising and human and institutional capacity on climate change mitigation, adaptation, impact reduction and early warning.
5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.
5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.

description.narrative: This summary covers the period July 2019 - December 2020. A sample of results from the BRDR program during the period include: - The Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology has, through the BRDR programme, begun engaging with the Commission on Human Rights and the Philippines Commission on Women to integrate rights based approaches and gender equality into disaster risk reduction activities. - A Regional Technical Working Group on Inclusive Approaches to Localization (TWG-IAL) has been established under the Asia Preparedeness Partnership (APP) that is active in Bangladesh, Cambodia, Myanmar, Pakistan, Philippines and Sri Lanka. Both BRDR and APP are committed to exploring how human rights and gender equal approachens can enhance prparedeness for responses at local levels. The establishment of the TWG-IAL is an example of how the BRDR programme is influencing other DRR programmes in the region. - The 15th Regional Consultative Committee on Disaster Management (RCC) took place during January 2020. "Enhancing Regional Cooperation and Coherence for Resilient and Inclusive Societies" was the theme of this 15th RCC that took place in Bangkok. - The Bangkok Statement issued at the 15th RCC meeting highlights the commitments of delegates and observers of the meeting to call upon parties of the UN frameworks to uphold their commitments in implementing inclusive DRR and CR strategies and action plans at national and local level; strengthen their efforts to integrate gender equality in DRR and CR; engage with and build capacities to support inclusive resilience; and work towards promoting risk-informed development. - The Municipality of Bhraratpur, Chitwan Province of Nepal, and Municipality of Itogon, Benguet Province of the Philippines have recognized the importance of the program in their respective areas by jointly implementing the BRDR activities, and have expressed strong support to build the capacities of the municipalities.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Syftet med insatsen är att bidra till villkoren för en stabil och varaktig fred i Colombia med ett nationellt, territoriellt och rättighetsbaserat perspektiv. Programmet får 63,8 MSEK från Sidas finansiering mellan 2017-2021.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The objective of the contributin is to contribute to the conditions of a stable and lasting peace in Colombia with a national, territorial, and rights-based perspective. The program will receive 63,8 MSEK of Sida funding between 2017-2021.

tag.narrative: 10.2 - By 2030, empower and promote the social, economic and political inclusion of all, irrespective of age, sex, disability, race, ethnicity, origin, religion or economic or other status.

15.4 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att bevara bergsekosystemen, inklusive deras biologiska mångfald, i syfte att öka deras förmåga att producera nytta som behövs för en hållbar utveckling.

16.7 - Säkerställa ett lyhört, inkluderande, deltagandebaserat och representativt beslutsfattande på alla nivåer.
