title.narrative: Regional Rights Resource Team (RRRT) in the Pacific

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Insatsen syftar till att främja och öka respekten för demokrati och mänskliga rättigheter och jämställdhet i Oceanien, och att bidra till att öka det legala skyddet mot våld för kvinnor och flickor och öka tillgången till rättvisa för de som utsätts för av våld, att stärka kapaciteten och kunskapen hos civila samhällets aktörer om mänskliga rättigheter, jämställdhet och hur de kan bidra till att stoppa våld mot kvinnor och flickor, i Oceanien. Insatsen förväntas bidra till genomförandet av utvecklingsagendan 2030 genom att bredda kunskapen om mänskliga rättigheter, jämställdhet och hur man kan använda rättighetsperspektivet inom utvecklingssektorer såsom miljö/klimat och fiske.
Regional Righs Resource Team (RRRT) är verksamma inom den regionala mellanstatliga organisationen Secretariat of Pacific Community (SPC). SPC är en av de största regionala utvecklingsaktörerna i Stilla Havsregionon. RRRT är ett starkt och kompetent team som arbetar innovativt och målinriktat med att öka kunskapen om mänskliga rättigheter i regionen. RRRT arbetar med att stärka staters kapacitet och kunskap om mänskliga rättigheter och har bidragit till att fler länder i Stilla havsregionen har ratificerat centrala konventioner om mänskliga rättigheter, de bidrar också med teknisk expertis i lagstiftningsprocesser, och utbildar personer inom regering, myndigheter och rättsväsende i mänskliga rättigheter. RRRT arbetar också med att förbättra förutsättningarna för civilsamahällets aktörer att efterfråga mänskliga rättigheter och ansvarsutkrävande då staterna brister.
RRRT har utvecklat en arbetsplan för 2017-2021 som består av tre huvudkomponenter:
1. Mänskliga rättigheter och god samhällstyrning (vilket inkluderar såväl stöd till staterna i regionen som stöd till att stärka den mellanstatliga miljöorganisationen SPC's kompetens om mänskliga rättigheter, jämställdhet och rättihetsperspektivet i relation till miljö/klimat och fiske) 2. Ökad tillgång till rättvisa för kvinnor och flickor som blivit utsatta för våld. 3. Förbättra förutsättningarna för civila samhället och lokala samhällen att främja mänskliga rättigheter och minska våldet mot kvinnor och barn.
Inom ramen för deras arbetsplan kommer RRRT bidra med sin expertis kring mänskliga rättigheter, jämställdhet och rättighetsperspektivet för att stärka SPC kapacitet att tillämpa rättighetsperspektivet och integrera jämställdhet inom sektorer såsom miljö, klimat och fiske i syfte att bidra till att öka synergierna mellan mänskliga rättigheter, jämställdhet och andra utvecklingssektorer som miljö/klimat och fiske.
I Oceanien har Sida som ett led i att genomföra Sveriges strategi för Asien och Oceanien också ingått stöd till EU's Marina Partnerskap i Oceaninen och, planerar att ingå stöd med bl.a. UN WOMEN och Internationella Juristkommissionen (ICJ) om ett regionalt program (Equal Access to Justice) öka tillgång till rättvisa in rättsväsendet kvinnor som inkluderar insatser i Oceanien, och att ingå ett regionalt stöd till FN's högkommissarie för mänskliga rättigheter (OHCHR) vilket inkluderar en del för Oceaninen. Sida kommer att säkerställa att samtliga insatser kommer att koordineras och följas upp i sin helhet i syfte att öka möjligheterna till samordning och synergier mellan insatserna.
Ambassaden gör bedömningen att stödet till SPC och RRRT Business plan har goda förutsättningar att bidra till genomförandet av regeringens strategi för Asien och Oceanien.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The contribution aims to contribute to promote and increase respect for human rights and, contribute to increase the legal protection of women and girls from violence, increase their access to justice in cases of violence and abuse and, strengthen the enabling environments for civil society and communities to advocate for human rights, gender equality and ending violence against women, in the Pacific region. The contribution will contribute to the implementation of Agenda 2030 on sustainable development by contributing to improve the knowledge of regional actors about human rights and how to apply a human rights based approach in sectors addressing challenges to the environment, climate change and the fisheries.
The Regional Rights Resource Team (RRRT) operates under the umbrella of the intergovernmental organization: Secretariat of the Pacific Communities (SPC), which is one of the largest development actors in the Pacific Region. RRRT has a strong and competent team that has proven to work innovatively to improve the knowledge and interest about human rights in the Pacific region. RRRT support government’s capacity and knowledge about human rights and has contributed to stronger commitments to human rights instruments among the Pacific countries and, provides training of high level government officials, authorities, and judiciary in human rights. RRRT are also targeting the capacity of civil society actors and communities to require accountability, protection and realization of human rights.
RRRT has developed a business plan for 2017-2021 consisting of three main pillars: 1. Human Rights and good governance (including support to Pacific states and mainstreaming of human rights, gender equality and how to use a human rights based approach in SPC with as specific focus on Environment/climate and fisheries) 2. End violence against women and girls 3. Enabling environment for civil society and communities.
After dialogue with the Embassy, RRRT has agreed to include within the framework of their Business Plan RRRT the provision of expertise on human rights, gender equality and the rights based approach to strengthen the overall capacity SPC to apply a human rights based approach to sectors such as environment, climate and the fisheries.
The Embassy makes the assessment that this contribution will contribute to the implementation of the Swedish strategy for development cooperation in Asia and the Pacific.

tag.narrative: 10.2 - By 2030, empower and promote the social, economic and political inclusion of all, irrespective of age, sex, disability, race, ethnicity, origin, religion or economic or other status.

10.2 - Till 2030 möjliggöra och verka för att alla människors, oavsett ålder, kön, funktionsnedsättning, ras, etnicitet, ursprung, religion eller ekonomisk eller annan ställning, blir inkluderade i det sociala, ekonomiska och politiska livet.

13.b - Främja mekanismer för att höja förmågan till effektiv klimatrelaterad planering och förvaltning i de minst utvecklade länderna, med särskilt fokus på kvinnor, ungdomar samt lokala och marginaliserade samhällen.

13.b - Promote mechanisms for raising capacity for effective climate change-related planning and management in least developed countries and small island developing States, including focusing on women, youth and local and marginalized communities.

14.7 - By 2030, increase the economic benefits to small island developing States and least developed countries from the sustainable use of marine resources, including through sustainable management of fisheries, aquaculture and tourism.

14.7 - Till 2030 öka den ekonomiska nyttan för små önationer under utveckling och de minst utvecklade länderna av ett hållbart nyttjande av marina resurser, bland annat genom en hållbar förvaltning av fiske, vattenbruk och turism.
16.1 - Avsevärt minska alla former av våld och dödligt våld överallt.
16.1 - Significantly reduce all forms of violence and related death rates everywhere.
16.3 - Främja rättssäkerheten på nationell och internationell nivå samt säkerställa lika tillgång till rättvisa för alla.
16.3 - Promote the rule of law at the national and international levels and ensure equal access to justice for all.
16.7 - Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.
16.7 - Säkerställa ett lyhört, inkluderande, deltagandebaserat och representativt beslutsfattande på alla nivåer.
5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.
5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.

description.narrative: Introduction RRRT has continued to implement RRRT Business Plan and the implementation went well during the year. RRRT recruited 11 new staff and has in total 32 staff members whereof 19 are located int the Suva office in Fiji and 13 staff members are working in country. There has been a steady demand from the Pacific Islands Countries to get technical assistance from RRRT. RRRT has invested in developing monitoring and evaluation capacity of staff and carried out two MPMEAL workshops in 2018/2019. RRRT is also developing knowledge products such as the Pacific Human Rights Law digest and video tools for the establishment of new National Human Rights Institutions. RRRT has developed a new Visibility Strategy 2019-2021 and invested in communication activities and communication products. During the period July 2018 to June 2019 RRRT has reported on the results and implemented 87 % of scheduled activities in the annual workplan. Below a few illustrative examples of progress towards results. 1. Human rights and Good Governance Under this result area RRRT has contributed to significant progress in relation to three of four outcome areas. More PIC's have ratified, implemented and tracked progress against regional and international human rights commitments. This objective seeks to strengthen PIC governments' knowledge, capacity and will to fulfil human rights commitments. RRRT supports the PICs in many ways such as report writing, legal and policy advise, and how to develop the capacity of responsible government institutions and human rights mechanisms. In this work RRRT collaborate closely with relevant partners such as OHCHR, APF, UNICEF and UN Women. Examples of achievements: - Five countries have cited human rights or good governance standards in Ministry budgets and plans. - The ICs (Fiji, RMI, Kiribati and Samoa) has ratified 8 international human rights instruments (CAT, ICCPR, ICESCR and CRPD) during the period. - RRRT supported PICs developing and submitting reports to the United Nations Human Rights Mechanisms (UPR and Treaty body reporting). - RRRT support 6 PICs (Vanuatu, Kiribati, RMI, Samoa, FSM and Tuvalu) to strengthen the National Human Rights Coordination Mechanism (NHRCM). The focus of the support has been to develop and strengthen internal capacity of these NHRCM to assure that they use a coordinated and systemic approach to treaty reporting and implementation. RRRT also build capacity about the UPR process and the functioning of UN Treaty bodies. There are currently 3 established NHRIs in the Pacific (Fiji, Tuvalu and Samoa) an increasing interest among PICs to establish National Human Rights Mechanisms (NHRIs) in the Pacific and currently 6 countries are in various stages of scoping processes. RRRT in partnership with APF and OHCHR two regional NHRI workshops; one on gender equality and the second one about human rights communication and education. RRRT has during the reporting period provided support to the existing NHRIs in Tuvalu, Fiji and Samoa. A highlight in the reporting year was a NHRI study and exchange tour to UK and to the 41st meeting of the Human Rights Council in Geneva. A joint side event organized with the support of Sweden, Australia, UK, OHCHR and GANHRI. The Swedish Ambassador to the United Nations in Geneva participated and provided remarks. RRRT states that there is evidence building up that PICs have increased the knowledge and capacity in good governance and human rights standards. RRRT has also during the reporting period supported the Pacific Community (SPC) Divisions and programs to incorporate rights-based approaches (RBA) into the work on Natural resource management, climate change and environmental protection. This work has included intensive technical support into specific project as well as input into SPC policies, guidelines and integrated programming as well as training of staff. The point of departure has been to use the UN Common Understanding on Human Rights Based Approach and PLANET principles. (Participation, Link to Rights, Accountability, Non-Discrimination, Empowerment and Transforming Social Norms). During the reporting period the momentum at SPC, as a whole, for human rights/gender mainstreaming and understanding of its potential increased remarkable, the result of proactive awareness work carried out by RRRT and SDP. A unit for integrated programming approach and the need for all SPC programs to consider impacts on human rights is a big step forward and in addition, work to develop a "People Centered Approach Strategy" built on pillars of human rights, gender equality, social inclusion and cultural heritage. The increased demand for HRBA/Gender Equality is positive, but it is also challenging for RRRT within existing human resources to meet all expectations. 2. Violence against women - Women and Girls have increased access to justice in cases of domestic violence RRRT report that they have managed to the deliver significant progress in this area. RRRT work on three levels: Macro - to support PIC to develop domestic legislation for the protection against family violence. Mezzo - to support and building up of the capacity of institutions and service providers in gender responsive application of legislation. Micro - awareness raising around the rights of survivors of violence and changing attitudes that reduce violence. Progress in the area of legislation is significant and most PIC have legislation against domestic violence and for family protection. A few countries still lack legislation (FSM and Nuie) in this area. The most challenging part is implementation. RRRT has together with UN Women supported the setting up of a Regional Working Group on the Implementation of Domestic Violence/ Family protection legislation. The purpose of the working group is to address the widespread use of violence against women and girls in the Pacific. The first meeting of the Regional Working group took place in May 2019. RRRT has worked to strengthen the Judiciary to ensure that the whole chain of judges, lawyers and police are not only well informed about the legislation but also understands the social dynamics affecting violence against women and girls to be able to respond appropriately. The Tonga Family Protection Legal Aid Centre, set up in 2017 with support from Australia and Sweden, was initially a pilot project in collaboration with the Ministry of Justice to provide free legal aid to survivors of violence. During the reporting period, the Legal Aid Centre provided services to 367 clients. The pilot project has demonstrated the need for a legal aid center in Tonga, and the Government will take on full responsibility for the cost of running the center from 2022. 3. Enabling environments: Civil Society and communities promote human rights, gender equality and EVAWG. RRRT reports that they managed to deliver moderate progress in this area. The objective of this result area is to build the capacity of civil society to advocate for human rights advances as well as increasing awareness and changing attitudes within communities around human rights and gender equality. One focus area of this objective is to conduct campaigns that leads to policy and legislative change or other human rights advances. Capacity development for CSO is another central component of this program. It has contributed with support to 24 CSO across the region. The program has also provided small grants for the implementation of advocacy campaigns on topics such as the age of consent, disability rights, seniors rights, youth, waste management, LGBTI, food security and displacement. One significant result under this objective is the MOU in Salomon Islands between Malaita Provincial Council of Women (MPCW) and Community leaders to implement SAFENET, a governmental referral mechanism that puts organisations and people in the frontline of dealing with survivors of domestic violence. The funding enabled the dialogue between MPCE and to develop the MOU which outlines their responsibilities when dealing with domestic violence. RRRT has reported that some activities in this results area has been delayed due to SPC procurement policy procedures.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

1. Mänskliga rättigheter och god samhällstyrning (vilket inkluderar såväl stöd till staterna i regionen som stöd till att stärka den mellanstatliga miljöorganisationen SPC's kompetens om mänskliga rättigheter, jämställdhet och rättihetsperspektivet i relation till miljö/klimat och fiske) 2. Ökad tillgång till rättvisa för kvinnor och flickor som blivit utsatta för våld. 3. Förbättra förutsättningarna för civila samhället och lokala samhällen att främja mänskliga rättigheter och minska våldet mot kvinnor och barn.
Inom ramen för deras arbetsplan kommer RRRT bidra med sin expertis kring mänskliga rättigheter, jämställdhet och rättighetsperspektivet för att stärka SPC kapacitet att tillämpa rättighetsperspektivet och integrera jämställdhet inom sektorer såsom miljö, klimat och fiske i syfte att bidra till att öka synergierna mellan mänskliga rättigheter, jämställdhet och andra utvecklingssektorer som miljö/klimat och fiske.
I Oceanien har Sida som ett led i att genomföra Sveriges strategi för Asien och Oceanien också ingått stöd till EU's Marina Partnerskap i Oceaninen och, planerar att ingå stöd med bl.a. UN WOMEN och Internationella Juristkommissionen (ICJ) om ett regionalt program (Equal Access to Justice) öka tillgång till rättvisa in rättsväsendet kvinnor som inkluderar insatser i Oceanien, och att ingå ett regionalt stöd till FN's högkommissarie för mänskliga rättigheter (OHCHR) vilket inkluderar en del för Oceaninen. Sida kommer att säkerställa att samtliga insatser kommer att koordineras och följas upp i sin helhet i syfte att öka möjligheterna till samordning och synergier mellan insatserna.
Ambassaden gör bedömningen att stödet till SPC och RRRT Business plan har goda förutsättningar att bidra till genomförandet av regeringens strategi för Asien och Oceanien.

description.narrative: Introduction RRRT has continued to implement RRRT Business Plan and the implementation went well during the year. RRRT recruited 11 new staff and has in total 32 staff members whereof 19 are located int the Suva office in Fiji and 13 staff members are working in country. There has been a steady demand from the Pacific Islands Countries to get technical assistance from RRRT. RRRT has invested in developing monitoring and evaluation capacity of staff and carried out two MPMEAL workshops in 2018/2019. RRRT is also developing knowledge products such as the Pacific Human Rights Law digest and video tools for the establishment of new National Human Rights Institutions. RRRT has developed a new Visibility Strategy 2019-2021 and invested in communication activities and communication products. During the period July 2018 to June 2019 RRRT has reported on the results and implemented 87 % of scheduled activities in the annual workplan. Below a few illustrative examples of progress towards results. 1. Human rights and Good Governance Under this result area RRRT has contributed to significant progress in relation to three of four outcome areas. More PIC's have ratified, implemented and tracked progress against regional and international human rights commitments. This objective seeks to strengthen PIC governments' knowledge, capacity and will to fulfil human rights commitments. RRRT supports the PICs in many ways such as report writing, legal and policy advise, and how to develop the capacity of responsible government institutions and human rights mechanisms. In this work RRRT collaborate closely with relevant partners such as OHCHR, APF, UNICEF and UN Women. Examples of achievements: - Five countries have cited human rights or good governance standards in Ministry budgets and plans. - The ICs (Fiji, RMI, Kiribati and Samoa) has ratified 8 international human rights instruments (CAT, ICCPR, ICESCR and CRPD) during the period. - RRRT supported PICs developing and submitting reports to the United Nations Human Rights Mechanisms (UPR and Treaty body reporting). - RRRT support 6 PICs (Vanuatu, Kiribati, RMI, Samoa, FSM and Tuvalu) to strengthen the National Human Rights Coordination Mechanism (NHRCM). The focus of the support has been to develop and strengthen internal capacity of these NHRCM to assure that they use a coordinated and systemic approach to treaty reporting and implementation. RRRT also build capacity about the UPR process and the functioning of UN Treaty bodies. There are currently 3 established NHRIs in the Pacific (Fiji, Tuvalu and Samoa) an increasing interest among PICs to establish National Human Rights Mechanisms (NHRIs) in the Pacific and currently 6 countries are in various stages of scoping processes. RRRT in partnership with APF and OHCHR two regional NHRI workshops; one on gender equality and the second one about human rights communication and education. RRRT has during the reporting period provided support to the existing NHRIs in Tuvalu, Fiji and Samoa. A highlight in the reporting year was a NHRI study and exchange tour to UK and to the 41st meeting of the Human Rights Council in Geneva. A joint side event organized with the support of Sweden, Australia, UK, OHCHR and GANHRI. The Swedish Ambassador to the United Nations in Geneva participated and provided remarks. RRRT states that there is evidence building up that PICs have increased the knowledge and capacity in good governance and human rights standards. RRRT has also during the reporting period supported the Pacific Community (SPC) Divisions and programs to incorporate rights-based approaches (RBA) into the work on Natural resource management, climate change and environmental protection. This work has included intensive technical support into specific project as well as input into SPC policies, guidelines and integrated programming as well as training of staff. The point of departure has been to use the UN Common Understanding on Human Rights Based Approach and PLANET principles. (Participation, Link to Rights, Accountability, Non-Discrimination, Empowerment and Transforming Social Norms). During the reporting period the momentum at SPC, as a whole, for human rights/gender mainstreaming and understanding of its potential increased remarkable, the result of proactive awareness work carried out by RRRT and SDP. A unit for integrated programming approach and the need for all SPC programs to consider impacts on human rights is a big step forward and in addition, work to develop a "People Centered Approach Strategy" built on pillars of human rights, gender equality, social inclusion and cultural heritage. The increased demand for HRBA/Gender Equality is positive, but it is also challenging for RRRT within existing human resources to meet all expectations. 2. Violence against women - Women and Girls have increased access to justice in cases of domestic violence RRRT report that they have managed to the deliver significant progress in this area. RRRT work on three levels: Macro - to support PIC to develop domestic legislation for the protection against family violence. Mezzo - to support and building up of the capacity of institutions and service providers in gender responsive application of legislation. Micro - awareness raising around the rights of survivors of violence and changing attitudes that reduce violence. Progress in the area of legislation is significant and most PIC have legislation against domestic violence and for family protection. A few countries still lack legislation (FSM and Nuie) in this area. The most challenging part is implementation. RRRT has together with UN Women supported the setting up of a Regional Working Group on the Implementation of Domestic Violence/ Family protection legislation. The purpose of the working group is to address the widespread use of violence against women and girls in the Pacific. The first meeting of the Regional Working group took place in May 2019. RRRT has worked to strengthen the Judiciary to ensure that the whole chain of judges, lawyers and police are not only well informed about the legislation but also understands the social dynamics affecting violence against women and girls to be able to respond appropriately. The Tonga Family Protection Legal Aid Centre, set up in 2017 with support from Australia and Sweden, was initially a pilot project in collaboration with the Ministry of Justice to provide free legal aid to survivors of violence. During the reporting period, the Legal Aid Centre provided services to 367 clients. The pilot project has demonstrated the need for a legal aid center in Tonga, and the Government will take on full responsibility for the cost of running the center from 2022. 3. Enabling environments: Civil Society and communities promote human rights, gender equality and EVAWG. RRRT reports that they managed to deliver moderate progress in this area. The objective of this result area is to build the capacity of civil society to advocate for human rights advances as well as increasing awareness and changing attitudes within communities around human rights and gender equality. One focus area of this objective is to conduct campaigns that leads to policy and legislative change or other human rights advances. Capacity development for CSO is another central component of this program. It has contributed with support to 24 CSO across the region. The program has also provided small grants for the implementation of advocacy campaigns on topics such as the age of consent, disability rights, seniors rights, youth, waste management, LGBTI, food security and displacement. One significant result under this objective is the MOU in Salomon Islands between Malaita Provincial Council of Women (MPCW) and Community leaders to implement SAFENET, a governmental referral mechanism that puts organisations and people in the frontline of dealing with survivors of domestic violence. The funding enabled the dialogue between MPCE and to develop the MOU which outlines their responsibilities when dealing with domestic violence. RRRT has reported that some activities in this results area has been delayed due to SPC procurement policy procedures.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 FORUM-ASIA har ansökt om fortsatt kärnstöd från ambassaden under perioden 2020-2022 för genomförande av sin Strategiska Plan (2016-2022).
FORUM-ASIA är en regional ideell organisation i Asien, med huvudkontor i Bangkok, Thailand. Organisationen grundades 1991 med uppdraget att stärka mänskliga rättighetsrörelserna i Asien genom kapacitetsuppbyggnad av mänskliga rättighetsförsvarare (HRD) och civilsamhällets organisationer (CSO). I uppdraget ingår även att bygga koalitioner med likasinnade organisationer och att skapa gemensam opinion för MR-frågor på faktabaserad grund. FORUM-ASIA har rådgivande status till FN: s ekonomiska och sociala råd (ECOSOC), liksom ett ”rådgivande förhållande” med ASEAN: s regeringskommission för mänskliga rättigheter (AICHR). För närvarande har FORUM ASIA 81 aktiva medlemsorganisationer från 21 länder i Asien. FORUM ASIA har sitt huvudkontor i Bangkok, men också mindre kontor i Genève, Jakarta och Kathmandu. FORUM-ASIA är medlemsbaserad demokratiskt styrd organisation med en styrelse som röstas fram av 81 medlemmarna.
Ambassadens bidrag är totalt 19 760 000 SEK vilket motsvarar cirka 23% av organisationens totala budget. Bidraget ska täcka för kärnkostnader som hyra, löner och administrationskostnader samt kostnader för genomförande av organisationens kärnverksamhet i form av program för utbildning och kapacitetsutveckling av civil samhälle organisationer och framtagande av studier och informationsmaterial kring MR/Demo och ett program för att skydda MR försvarare.
FORUM-ASIA anpassade sig omedelbart till COVID-19 genom att arrangera webbseminarier tillsammans med medlemmar och partners rörande mänskliga rättigheter och utvecklingsfrågor. Dessa webinarer bidrog till att, genom subregionala plattformar, öka medvetenhet och avkräva ansvarsskyldighet för stater vilket påverkade utfärdandet av AICHR Joint Statement on Covid 19 samt UN Special Rapporteur (UN SR) guidelines on Freedom of Assembly and Association (FoAA) under pandemin.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 FORUM-ASIA is a member-based international NGO with a Secretariat based in Bangkok. It was founded in 1991 with the mission to strengthen the human rights movement in Asia through capacity building of human rights defenders (HRDs) and civil society organizations (CSOs), coalition building with like-minded organizations, solidarity actions and evidence-based advocacy . It has Special Consultative Status with the United Nations Economic and Social Council (ECOSOC), as well as a 'consultative relationship' with ASEAN Intergovernmental Commission on Human Rights (AICHR). At present, FA has 81 active member organizations from 21 countries in Asia. FORUM-ASIA has its headquarter in Bangkok, but also smaller offices in Geneva, Jakarta and Kathmandu. The organisation is a democratic, member based organisation with a board elected by the 81 members.
The Embassy contribution to FORUM-ASIA is total 19 760 000 SEK which corresponds to approximately 23% of the organization's total budget. The grant will cover core costs such as rent, salaries and administrative costs and for the implementation of organizations core activities in the form of programs for strengthening capacity and trainings of civil society organisation and Human Rights Defenders. Development of studies and research papers on Human Rights and HRD protection programs.
FORUM-ASIA immediately adapted to the COVID-19 and arranged webinars together with members and partners on different human rights and development issues, policies, and procedures formulated which are detrimental to human rights and democratic developments. Raising awareness and demanding for accountability of states through sub-regional platforms, the webinars influenced the issuance of AICHR Joint statement on COVID-19 pandemic and UN Special Rapporteur (UN SR) guidelines on Freedom of Assembly and Association (FoAA) during the pandemic.

title.narrative: COVID-19 Continued support to the minority RAE communities 2018-2021
COVID-19 Continued support to the minority RAE communities 2018-2021

description.narrative: DRC proposal "Strengthening Community Resilience to Conflict" is motivated by their assessment on continuous inter-ethnic division and alienation as factors of potential inter-ethnic conflict in Kosovo. To address this, DRC proposes a set of activities grouped under an additional component of Grant Agreement 10898 (Specific Objective and Activity Area 4), conceived as an 18-month pilot that will focus on creating or strengthening linkages based on in-depth understanding of the dynamics at the community level, which may vary from a location to the other. The pilot is conceived in line with several points listed under Expected Result 2 of the Results Strategy for Sweden’s Reform Cooperation with Eastern Europe, the Western Balkans and Turkey 2014—2020, which refers to achieving “strengthened democracy, greater respect for human rights and a more fully developed state under the rule of law”. Namely, in direct reference to the above-mentioned Expected Result, the proposed activities will “target increasing trust within and among the parties […] and contribute to reconciliation, so as to counter the emergence of new conflicts”. They will aim to promote “increased trust and reconciliation between parties”, to “strengthen the rights of the Roma […], ethnic and religious minorities”, and to “increase recognition and respect for such groups”.

New/additional funds to address COVID-19 New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Danish Refugee Council has presented a proposal to Sida for implementing a project "Support for social entrepreneurship and socio-economic empowerment of minority communities in Kosovo 2018-2021". The proposal corresponds well with Multi Dimensional Poverty Analysis that Sida in Kosovo conducted in 2017. Compared to the previous cooperation phase, the proposal focuses more on the empowerment of the most marginalized and underrepresented groups, notably RAE communities not limited only to Roma Mahalla in Mitrovica. The proposal is highly relevant and corresponds with current Result Strategy for Sweden's Reform Cooperation with Eastern Europe, Western Balkans and Turkey 2014–2020.The budget for the project is 26 000 000 SEK.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att bekämpa covid-19 Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 DRC har presenterat ett förslag till SIDA om stöd till minoritetssamhällen i Kosovo som gäller entreprenörskap och socio-ekonomiskt egenmakt under perioden 2018-2021. Förslaget ligger väl i linje med den multidimensionella fattigdomsanalysen som SIDA i Kosovo genomförde 2017. Projektet är utformat för att aktivt engagera de lokala och centrala myndigheterna i Kosovo och stödja dem i genomförandet av regeringens strategi med namnet Strategy for Communities and Return [1] samt Strategy for Inclusion of Roma and Ashkali Communities in the Kosovo Society 2017-2021. Projektet bidrar också till strategin Small and Medium Enterprise Development Strategy of Kosovo 2012-2016 - med en vision mot 2020, som kräver en "förbättrad ställning för kvinnliga entreprenörer, ungdomar, minoriteter, särskilda grupper och stöd till entreprenörer i missgynnade zoner" ( Strategiskt mål 7). I jämförelse med den tidigare samarbetsperioden, fokuserar detta förslag mer på egenmakt hos de mest marginaliserade och underrepresenterade grupperna, i synnerlighet RAE, och inte endast Roma Mahalla i Mitrovitca. Vidare är förslaget högst relevant och korresponderar med den nuvarande Result Strategy for Sweden's Reform Cooperation with Eastern Europe, Western Balkans and Turkey 2014–2020. Budgeten för projektet är 26 000 000 SEK. Denna föreslagna intervention återspeglar följande policymarkörer: Jämställdhet 1 – Viktigt mål; Demokrati och mänskliga rättigheter 1 - Viktigt mål; Stöd till miljöarbetet 1 - Viktigt mål Andra markörer är: Konfliktförebyggande åtgärder, fred och säkerhet 2 - Huvudmål Sysselsättning 1 - Viktigt mål
Danish Refugee Council has presented a proposal to Sida "Support for social entrepreneurship and socio-economic empowerment of minority communities in Kosovo during the period 2018-2021". The proposal corresponds well with Multi Dimensional Poverty Analysis that Sida in Kosovo conducted in 2017. The project is designed to actively engage Kosovo local and central authorities and support them in implementing the Kosovo Government policies for Communities and Return as well as Strategy for Inclusion of Roma and Ashkali Communities in the Kosovo Society 2017-2021. The project also contributes to the Small and Medium Enterprise Development Strategy of Kosovo 2012-2016 with a vision towards 2020, which calls for “Improving the position of female entrepreneurs, youngsters, minorities, specific group and support to entrepreneurs in disadvantaged zones” (Strategic goal 7). Compared to the previous cooperation phase, the proposal focuses more on the empowerment of the most marginalized and underrepresented groups, notably RAE communities not limited only to Roma Mahalla in Mitrovica. The proposal is highly relevant and corresponds with current Result Strategy for Sweden's Reform Cooperation with Eastern Europe, Western Balkans and Turkey 2014–2020.The budget for the project is 26 000 000 SEK. This proposed intervention reflects the following policy markers: Gender equality 1 - Significant objective; Democracy and Human Rights 1 - Significant objective; Aid to environment 1 - Significant objective Other markers are: Conflict prevention, peace and security 2 - Principal objective Employment 1 - Significant objective

description.narrative: The project activities implemented in Roma Mahalla/Mahala and Dy Korriku/Sitnicko Naselje have proven to be successful in the short-to-medium term. They have resulted in enhanced access to income generation opportunities and skills development, especially for youth and women. The long-term sustainability of the project faces some challenges, namely in terms of the lack of commitment by central and local institutions to assume full responsibility towards RAE communities inclusion and protection. DRC has been instrumental in facilitating interaction and access to services, such as unemployment benefits for RAE communities. It should be noted that some reluctance still exists within RAE communities to participate in the vocational-educational training programmes offered by the Kosovo system. The NGO grant schemes have yielded positive results, but some gaps remain open particularly in the area of education. DRC plans to support a local NGO RADC to set up and manage a fully-fledged Learning Centre in Roma Mahalla/Mahala in line with the provisions of the relevant Administrative Instructions of the Ministry of Education and Technology. Activities that focuses on promoting inclusive resilience through livelihoods as a means to bring communities together has started to show positive results. The geographical scope of support has included the municipality of Zvecan/Zveçan and the area North to the Ibar river. The interaction with municipal authorities has been positive, despite some challenges due to the political situation. These challenges, although resulting is slight delays, have not significantly affected the work plan - DRC and its local implementing partners showed flexibility to adjust to a new socio-political dynamics and circumstances. The situation in which the residents of North Kosovo live is always particularly problematic – for instance, during CoVID-19 they had to comply with double restrictions of movement (one from the Kosovo Government and one from Serbia's Government). DRC will explore the possibilities to continue supporting rural development by expanding it to all four North municipalities. This would contribute to strengthen individual and community resilience. The impact of CoVID-19 was felt particularly in relation to conflict perspective. Planned activities with youth groups had to be postponed and revised. Consultations with a local NGO partner are still ongoing. Discussions on the psychological effects on CoVID-19 are held, correct information are disseminated and the most vulnerable families and individuals are identified, registered and supported with food, hygienic and sanitary material.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: UNDP Strategic Collaboration Framework on Environment and Climate Change
UNDP Strategiskt samarbetsramverk Miljö och Klimat

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 UNDP har ansökt till Sida om SEK 380 000 000 för finansiering av "UNDP-Sida Strategiskt samarbetsramverk inom miljö och klimat", ett program som ska implementeras både på global nivå och på landnivå under perioden 2019 - 2023. Det syftar ytterst till att stödja den övergripande visionen i UNDP:s Strategiska plan 2018 - 2021 för genomförandet av Agenda 2030: "att hjälpa länder att uppnå hållbar utveckling genom att utrota fattigdomen i alla dess former och dimensioner, påskynda strukturomvandlingar för en hållbar utveckling och bygga motståndskraft mot kriser och chocker". Det kommer ske genom stöd till programmets två byggstenar:
1) Omkring 80% av stödet går till specifika UNDP-genomförda projekt och initiativ på landnivå och global nivå inom tre utvalda programområden som både syftar till att stärka det tematiska arbetet samt integration och synergier mellan områdena: (a) Hållbar förvaltning och användning av ekosystem, biologisk mångfald och naturkapital, (b) Hållbar vatten- och havsförvaltning, och (c) Förbättrade klimatåtgärder för en hållbar utveckling, samt nexusområdet Hållbara livsmedelssystem som har bäring på alla programområden, och 2) Omkring 20% av stödet går till stärkt organisatorisk kapacitet och prestation hos UNDP för att underlätta övergången till mer strategiska, integrerade och programmatiska arbetsmetoder inom miljö och klimatområdet och ett stärkt lärande. Sammantaget förväntas det leda till förbättrade och mer transformativa resultat på landnivå. Syftet är att bidra till ett programtänk som gör att helheten blir större än summan av samtliga UNDP:s miljö- och klimatprojekt och att fragmenteringen minskar.
Förslaget innebär att allt globalt stöd från Sida till UNDP inom miljö- och klimatområdet samlas under ett paraplyprogram, inklusive de pågående Sida-stödda insatserna inom vatten och hav (Water and Ocean Governance och Ocean Innovation Challenge). Samtliga dessa tematiska områden samt den kapacitetsbyggande delen är relevanta för strategin för Sveriges globala utvecklingssamarbete inom hållbar miljö, hållbart klimat och hav, samt hållbart nyttjande av naturresurser 2018 - 2022. Programmet är dessutom i linje med regeringens strategi för samarbetet med UNDP 2017 - 2021 och i synnerhet att UNDP utvecklar sin verksamhet inom klimat, ekosystem, motståndskraft och miljömässigt hållbara samhällen.
Mellan 5 - 10 pilotländer kommer gemensamt väljas ut av Sida och UNDP, med fokus på de mest fattiga länderna, för att genomföra aktiviteterna under programmets två byggstenar. UNDP har föreslagit en indikativ lista med 11 länder som utgått från ett antal överenskomna kriterier. Dessa inkluderar; efterfrågan från länderna, att UNDP har en stor projektportfölj i landet med NDC-stöd samt stöd från vertikala fonder, ett starkt fokus på LDC:s och på Sidas samarbetsländer samt åtminstone inkluderar en liten ö-nation under utveckling och ett konfliktland. Sida är överens om de föreslagna länderna och bedömer att det finns goda möjligheter för UNDP att uppnå bättre resultat på landnivå.
UNDP är Sidas avtalspart och kommer vara huvudansvarig för att genomföra och samordna programmet. En rad andra partner (FN-organ - inte minst UNEP, enskilda organisationer, filantroper och privata sektorn) kommer dessutom samverka med UNDP i genomförandet av insatsen. Ett tungt vägande skäl till att UNDP bedöms som lämplig genomförare är att UNDP har det operativa mandatet inom FN att stödja samarbetsländerna inom området ”hållbar utveckling”, en fråga där Sverige har varit drivande.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 UNDP has applied to Sida for funding of SEK 380 000 000 to carry out the "UNDP-Sida Strategic Collaboration Framework on Environment and Climate Change", a programme that will be implemented at the global, regional and country level during the period 2019-2023. It primarily aims at supporting the overall vision of UNDP's Strategic Plan 2018-2021: "to help countries achieve sustainable development by eradicating poverty in all its forms and dimensions, accelerate structural transformations for sustainable development and build resilience to crises and shocks". This will be made possible by providing support for the programmes's two building blocks:
1) About 80 % in support of specific UNDP-implemented projects and initiatives in three selected program areas, aimed at strengthening both thematic work, as well as integration and synergies between the areas: (a) Sustainable management and use of ecosystems; biodiversity and natural capital; (b) Sustainable water and ocean governance and (c) Improved climate measures for sustainable development, as well as the nexus area of sustainable food systems where all programme areas are included, and
2) About 20 % of the support towards strengthening the organisational capacity and performance of UNDP to facilitate the transition to more strategic, integrated and programmatic practices that tie together all the projects in the area of environment and climate change and a stronger learning that put together are expected to lead to improved and more transformative results at the country level. The aim is to contribute to a programmatic approach making the whole larger than the sum of all UNDP-implemented environment and climate change projects and decrease fragmentation.
The contribution implies that all global support from Sida to UNDP in the area of environment and climate change will be collected under one umbrella programme, including the two on-going contributions within water and oceans (Water and Ocean Governance och Ocean Innovation Challenge). All the programme areas are relevant to the strategy for Sweden's global development cooperation on sustainable environment, sustainable climate and ocean, and sustainable use of natural resources 2018-2022. In addition, the programme is fully in line with the government's strategy for cooperation with UNDP 2017 - 2021 and above all that UNDP should develop its activities in climate change, ecosystems, resilience and environmentally sustainable communities.
Between 5-10 pilot countries will be selected jointly by Sida and UNDP, focusing on the poorest countries, to carry out the activities under the Programme's two building blocks. UNDP has proposed a preliminary list of 11 countries based on a number of agreed criteria. Thes include; country demand for the support, that UNDP has a large project portfolio in the country - NDC support including support from vertical funds, a strong focus on LDC's and Sida's partner countries and that at least one small island developing state and a conflict country are included. Sida is in agreement with the proposed countries and believes that in these countries there are opportunities for UNDP to link the various projects for better results.
While UNDP will be Sida's agreement partner and is primarily responsible for implementing and coordinating the Collaboration Framework, a number of other partners (UN agencies - not least UNEP, NGOs, philantropy, private sector) will cooperate with UNDP in the implementation. An important reason why UNDP is considered the appropriate implementing partner is that UNDP has the UN operational mandate to support the partner countries in the area of "sustainable development", which Sweden has been a proponent of.

The UNDP-Sida Strategic Collaboration Framework on Environment and Climate Change will ultimately contribute to the UNDP Strategic Plan 2018-2021 and the overall objective:"to help countries to achieve sustainable development by eradicating poverty in all its forms and dimensions, accelerating structural transformations for sustainable development and building resilience to crises and shocks". In order to do so, the programme primarily aims at strengthening UNDP's organisational capacity and performance in the area of environment and climate change to be able to deliver transformative results at country level, across the Signature Solutions.

tag.narrative: 1.4 - By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.

1.4 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla män och kvinnor, i synnerhet de fattiga och de utsatta, har lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, tillgång till grundläggande tjänster, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till arv, naturresurser, lämplig ny teknik och finansiella tjänster, inklusive mikrokrediter.
13.1 - Strengthen resilience and adaptive capacity to climate-related hazards and natural disasters in all countries.
13.1 - Stärka motståndskraften mot och förmågan till anpassning till klimatrelaterade faror och naturkatastrofer i alla länder.
13.2 - Integrate climate change measures into national policies, strategies and planning.
13.2 - Integrera klimatåtgärder i politik, strategier och planering på nationell nivå.

14.2 - By 2020, sustainably manage and protect marine and coastal ecosystems to avoid significant adverse impacts, including by strengthening their resilience, and take action for their restoration in order to achieve healthy and productive oceans.

14.2 - Senast 2020 förvalta och skydda marina och kustnära ekosystem på ett hållbart sätt för att undvika betydande negativa konsekvenser, bland annat genom att stärka deras motståndskraft, samt vidta åtgärder för att återställa dem i syfte att uppnå friska och produktiva hav.

15.1 - By 2020, ensure the conservation, restoration and sustainable use of terrestrial and inland freshwater ecosystems and their services, in particular forests, wetlands, mountains and drylands, in line with obligations under international agreements.

15.1 - Till 2020 bevara, återställa och hållbart använda ekosystem på land och i sötvatten och deras ekosystemtjänster, särskilt skogar, våtmarker, berg och torra områden, i enlighet med de skyldigheter som anges i internationella överenskommelser.
15.5 - Take urgent and significant action to reduce the degradation of natural habitats, halt the loss of biodiversity and, by 2020, protect and prevent the extinction of threatened species.

15.5 - Vidta omedelbara och betydande åtgärder för att minska förstörelsen av naturliga livsmiljöer, hejda förlusten av biologisk mångfald och senast 2020 skydda och förebygga utrotning av hotade arter.

5.a - Genomföra reformer för att ge kvinnor lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till finansiella tjänster, arv och naturresurser, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning

5.a - Undertake reforms to give women equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to ownership and control over land and other forms of property, financial services, inheritance and natural resources, in accordance with national laws.
6.5 - By 2030, implement integrated water resources management at all levels, including through transboundary cooperation as appropriate.
6.5 - Senast 2030 genomföra en integrerad förvaltning av vattenresurser på alla nivåer, när så är lämpligt genom gränsöverskridande samarbete.
7.1 - By 2030, ensure universal access to affordable, reliable and modern energy services.
7.1 - Senast 2030 säkerställa allmän tillgång till ekonomiskt överkomliga, tillförlitliga och moderna energitjänster.

description.narrative: It should be noted that this is not a fully-fledged Conclusion on Performance but covers the first reporting period of the UNDP Programme on Environment and Climate Change, January to April 2020. UNDP submitted a narrative progress report for this 4-month period in order to align with the reporting deadlines for the rest of the agreement period and also to trigger the first tranche of payment in July 2020. During the period assessed, the architecture around the UNDP programme on Environment and Climate Change has been set up, planning and anchoring at different levels have been carried out, recruitment of additional staff has started and the UNDP organisational capacity strengthening work was kicked off. In other words, the focus has been on process which means that results can only be presented at activity/output level. For this reporting period, none of the initial results can be directly linked to GLOBEN's strategy objectives. Sida assesses that this is reasonable. The annual report for 2020 will be submitted in April 2021 and the annual review meeting will be held in June, after which a comprehensive Conclusion on Performance can be developed, linking the results to the strategy objectives and Sida's thematic perspectives. Examples of initial results achieved: - COVID-19 - An assessment has been undertaken of the potential impact of the virus on the timely delivery of agreed results, as well as opportunities to use the Programme to more effectively respond to the socio-economic, environmental and climate needs of countries and communities during the medium and longer-term period of COVID-19 recovery. - Work planning and anchoring - To further validate the proposed 9 pilot countries, the Nature, Climate and Environment Team (NCE team) mapped existing work under UNDP’s Environment, climate, and energy portfolio in each pilot country. UNDP also began consultations with its Regional Bureaus for Africa, Asia-Pacific, and Latin America and the Caribbean as part of the validation and work planning process. This process will result in each pilot country having its own detailed work plan and budget. - Cross-cutting - The Programme has already started to achieve initial results, by leveraging initiatives aimed at strengthening internal capacities needed to achieve the environmental and climate change dimensions of UNDP’s Strategic Plan, including efforts to advance more integrated silo-breaking approaches. - Organisational capacity - The NCE Team has adopted a new management structure and workflow system to ensure synergies to deliver more effectively on the NCE dimensions of its Strategic Plan. To help to incentivise the shift away from siloed funds and units and do planning differently, UNDP has also rebranded its Global Environmental Finance Unit (focused on projects funded through GEF and GCF) and its additional portfolio of environment work funded by other sources into one group working on Nature, Climate and Energy (NCE). - Organisational capacity - Another example is that the NCE Team is collaborating closely with UNDP SDG integration and innovation Team which is helping the NCE Team to create the learning space for systems to be put in place for new ways of working in an integrated manner. For example, there is now increased collaboration between the Bureau for Policy and Programme Support (BPPS) and the Crisis Bureau (CB) to strengthen links between climate adaptation and DRR. To increase this collaboration, UNDP has established a task team which comprises staff from both Bureaus at all levels, with an initial focus on Africa. - Partnerships - UNDP and UNEP have organized a series of consultations designed to increase the strategic value and transformational impact of their collaboration. This includes a focus on advocacy and joint programming on climate action, biodiversity, and green economy themes already prioritised by the Programme. UNDP and FAO have also completed a series of consultations designed to increase collaboration on areas supported by the Programme, including sustainable food systems, ecosystem-based livelihoods, disaster risk mitigation, and linked efforts for rural poverty reduction. - Results framework - The results framework has been revised to include also results and indicators for the UNDP organisational capacity strengthening as well as for the pilot countries. - Staff - The recruitment of the additional staff aiming to support the implementation of the Programme has begun.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: COVID-19 UNFPA Jemen:Skydd av kvinnor och flickor från GBV
COVID-19 UNFPA Yemen: Protection of Women and Girls from GBV

description.narrative: New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Support to GBV prevention and services for survivors of GBV in Yemen

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Könsbaserat våld mot kvinnor och flickor är ett utbrett problem i Jemen och har förvärrats ytterligare av den väpnade konflikten som pågått sedan mars 2015. Konflikten har resulterat i en humanitär kris och lett till att cirka 2 miljoner (11,3 % av befolkningen) lever som internflyktingar. Detta har ökat hushållens sårbarhet, lett till att sociala strukturer kollapsat och ökat risken för kvinnor och flickor att utsättas för könsbaserat våld både inom och utanför hemmet. 11,3 miljoner människor uppskattas vara i behov av skydd från könsbaserat våld (såsom sexuellt våld, våld i hemmet, tvångsäktenskap, barnäktenskap, psykosocialt och emotionellt våld). Samtidigt är insatser mot könsbaserat våld starkt underfinansierade i Jemen, där givarna är få och främst inriktade på humanitära, direkt livräddande, insatser. USAIDs stopp av finansiering till organisationer som arbetar med sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och rättigheter har ytterligare minskat finansiering inom detta område.
UNFPA har inkommit med en ansökan om stöd till programmet My Safety, Our Future: The Protection of Women and Girls from Gender Based Violence in Yemen. Programmet syftar till att ha ett enhetligt angreppssätt för att öka tillgången till service för överlevare av könsbaserat våld samt arbeta förebyggande för att minska risken för könsbaserat våld. Programmet inkluderar därför direkt tillhandahållande av medicinska, psykosociala och juridiska tjänster, upprättandet av fungerande hänvisningsvägar för tillgång till vård, yrkes- och entreprenörsutbildningar för att öka försörjningsmöjligheterna för överlevare av könsbaserat våld, kunskapsspridning för att öka medvetenheten kring och minska negativa normer som leder till könsbaserat våld samt att arbeta med att integrera arbete med könsbaserat våld i det övriga humanitära arbetet i Jemenkrisen. Programmet kommer både att arbeta med redan existerande strukturer samt upprätta två nya center (i Sanaa och Al Hodeida) för medicinskt och psykosocialt stöd till kvinnor och flickor som utsatts för könsbaserat våld.
Programmet implementeras under två år med en total budget på USD 6 875 665. Ca 50% av budgeten finansieras av Sida, resterande av Schweiz och Nederländerna som ingår separata avtal med UNFPA.

sector.narrative: Ending violence against women and girls

tag.narrative: 3.8 - Achieve universal health coverage, including financial risk protection, access to quality essential health-care services and access to safe, effective, quality and affordable essential medicines and vaccines for all.

3.8 - Åstadkomma allmän hälso- och sjukvård för alla, som även skyddar mot ekonomisk risk, tillgång till grundläggande hälso- och sjukvård av god kvalitet liksom tillgång till säkra, effektiva och ekonomiskt överkomliga grundläggande läkemedel och vaccin av god kvalitet.
5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.

description.narrative: The programme is a comprehensive multi-sectorial response to gender based violence (GBV). Under the programme multi-sectorial services have been provided to GBV survivors in 12 targeted governorates. During 2018 a total of 17 814 women, men, boys and girls were provided with psycological support (13868 women, 1291 men, 1179 girls and 276 boys). 6658 were provided medical support, 3114 were given legal support and 1003 women and girls were given cash assistance based on criteria developed for GBV survivors. The cash assistance is a support enabling survivors to travel from one district/governorate to another to access the required services. 791 women and children received life skills services, 123 accessed safe shelters. Four women shelters in Sanaa, Aden och Al Hudaydah and Ibb were supported under the programme where women and children received short term protection and support in emergency situations. Four more shelters are under construction in Sanaa, Al Hudaydah Amran and Aden to meet the increasing need. Also referral pathways to facilitate access to GBV response services across 48 districts have been expanded. 48 case managers have been recruited and trained. These are in charge of receiving GBV victims and making sure the cases receive the necessary interventions (safety, medical, psycho-social and legal). A national toll free hot line service has been established that provides immediate counselling, service information and assistance to GBV survivors. During 2018 186 cases were provided with psychological and legal support via the hot line service and 719 cases were referred to different support services. Activities to promote sustainable livelihood opportunities and financial education for women who have been subject to GBV to enable them to take control of their income and gain financial independence have been carried out. 750 women (17-27 years) have received life skills training (including psychological support) to empower them socially and help integrate them into the society. 500 of these have thereafter received livelihood and economic empowerment training. (This part of the programme was however delayed due to a delay in getting permits for implementation for CARE International. Communities have been engaged and empowered to change cultural norms against GBV. Through its implementing partner Yemen Women Union, 12 community committees and 48 men-to men networks have been formed in targeted districts. Members include influential personalities within the communities including sheiks, religious leaders, local governing councils, and education/health workers, youth and IDPs. The community committees and the men-to men networks implemented a series of 12 community dialogues discussing sensitive topics such as girls education, child marriage and the most prevalent forms of GBV in the villages.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
